These sources are given in the public catalogue for comparison with other measurements, but are not used in the subsequent analysis. &#8722; Confidence 2: redshift based on a single emission line without additional information, several low S/N absorption features, or whose redshift confidence is increased by the identification of multiply-imaged systems (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S15\">3.6</a>). &#8722; Confidence 3: redshift based on multiple spectral features, or with additional information on a high S/N emission line (e.g., very clear asymmetry of the line, HST non-detection bluewards of the line).</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n<p>Association between prior and <tt>muselet</tt> sources. The two detection methods will most of the time identify the same sources, and we keep the prior sources by default when a clear match is found with <tt>muselet</tt> emission lines. It is important to note that significant spatial offsets can be found between the two sources, for example in the case of star-forming/photoionised gas trailing behind infalling galaxies in the cluster, or Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emission which is physically offset from the underlying UV continuum emission.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n<p>Merging of sources. Clumpy star-forming galaxies or very elongated lensed arcs tend to be separated into multiple prior sources. We identify them and perform a new extraction of the merged source as in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S13\">3.4</a> by aggregating their segmentation maps and combining their photometry.</p>\n</li>\n<li>\n<p>Defects and artefacts. We identify stellar spikes or cosmic ray residuals in the prior catalogue, as well as artefacts found by <tt>muselet</tt> in the cube due to strongly varying spectral continuum (typically low-mass stars or cluster members).</p>\n</li>\n</ul></p>\n<p>The resulting inspection information is stored in a database, and since each spectrum was reviewed independently by at least three users, the results are cross-matched during a consolidation phase, where a consensus is reached in case of disagreement between the users, and the entry is written in the catalogue.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S15\"></a>3.6. Assessment of multiple images</h3>\n<p>All sources with a reliable redshift in the catalogue are tested with the corresponding L<span class=\"smallcaps\">ENSTOOL</span> mass model of the cluster (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S25\">4</a>) to predict multiple images. As the precision of the lens model is typically 0<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq17.gif\"></span>5&#8722;0<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq18.gif\"></span>9 over the area of multiple images, and the density of objects in a given redshift plane is low, we easily find good matches for systems of images at the same redshift which are predicted to arise from the same source. We manually inspect the corresponding spectra of each matching candidate, as we expect precisely the same redshift and spectral features from multiple images. This assessment serves two purposes: (a) identifying multiple images in order to pinpoint truly independent sources, and (b) cross-checking the redshift measurements for background lensed sources.</p>\n<p>Indeed, the main spectral features identified for background galaxies through the redshift inspection are typically bright emission lines ([O&#8239;<span class=\"smallcaps\">II</span>], C&#8239;<span class=\"smallcaps\">III</span>], C&#8239;<span class=\"smallcaps\">IV</span>, Lyman-<i>&#945;</i>) or absorption features (rest-frame UV ISM absorptions or Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> break). Ambiguous redshifts are typically limited to an uncertainty between [O&#8239;<span class=\"smallcaps\">II</span>] and Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> as a single emission line, which produce very different lensing configurations between <i>z</i>&#8196;&#8764;&#8196;0.5&#8211;1.5 and <i>z</i>&#8196;&#8764;&#8196;3&#8211;7. The multiple-image assessment allows us to correct a very small number of erroneous redshifts (typically less than 3 images per cluster), and more importantly to boost the redshift confidence level to <i>zconf</i>&#8196;=&#8196;2 for faint line emitters with <i>zconf</i>&#8196;=&#8196;1 showing a clear matching counterimage predicted by the model.</p>\n<p>As new multiple images help us refine and improve the lensing model, this is an iterative process: we start by using only spectroscopically confirmed images from the most secure systems (having confidence levels 2 or 3) as constraints in the model, and make further predictions from the refined model. We systematically search for spectral features in all predicted counter-images, even when they are not included in the original catalogue, solving all possible inconsistencies. This process allows us to identify a small number (up to 5&#8211;10 per cluster) of images as faint emission lines in the narrow-band datacube, which were not identified originally by <tt>muselet</tt>. We include these images as additional entries in the catalogue by manually forcing their extraction, adopting a point source extraction aperture in the procedure described in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S13\">3.4</a>. A typical example of faint counter image discovered during the assessment is presented in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F5\">5</a>.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F5\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5.</span></a>\n<p>Example of faint Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emission (large yellow circle) detected near the position of the predicted counterimage from <tt>muselet</tt> source 641 in cluster MACS0329, at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;6.011 (small white circle). The image shows a smoothed narrow-band image at the peak wavelength of the emission. The dotted ellipse denotes the estimated 1-<i>&#963;</i> error region of the predicted location.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div></p>\n<p>Remaining strongly-lensed sources not matched to a given system are <i>zconf</i>&#8196;=&#8196;1 objects for which we are able to explain the lack of counterimage by either (a) its much lower magnification, (b) its strong contamination by a cluster member or foreground source, or (c) it being outside the MUSE FoV. Conversely, when the counterimage is predicted to be bright and isolated, but is not seen in the observations, we choose to entirely remove the <i>zconf</i>&#8196;=&#8196;1 source from the redshift catalogue due to the large uncertainty in the measured redshift.</p>\n<p>Multiple images are identified in a dedicated column (<tt>MUL</tt>) of the final spectroscopic catalogue: we adopt the usual notation <i>X</i>.<i>Y</i> where <i>X</i> identifies a system of multiple images and <i>Y</i> is a running number identifying all images for a given system.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S16\"></a>3.7. Cross-checks with public spectroscopic catalogues</h3>\n<p>We performed a comparison of our spectroscopic catalogues with available spectroscopy from VLT and HST in the literature, including some of the same MUSE observations included in our sample.</p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S17\"></a>3.7.1. Abell 2744 and Abell 370</h4>\n<p>First versions of the MUSE spectroscopic catalogues, using the same datasets but based on an earlier version of our data reduction and analysis process, were presented in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R78\">Mahler et al. (2018)</a> for Abell 2744 and in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R69\">Lagattuta et al. (2019)</a> for Abell 370. Both catalogues were cross-checked with available observations from the Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space (GLASS) (<a name=\"InR101\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R101\">Schmidt et al. 2014</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R108\">Treu et al. 2015</a>). The datacubes included in these publications were reduced and analysed using an earlier version of the reduction pipeline and MPDAF, which did not include autocalibration or the interstack masks, and which used older versions of <tt>ZAP</tt> and <tt>MUSELET</tt>. In light of the newly processed datacube and source inspection catalogues, we reviewed all of the low-confidence sources (<i>zconf</i>&#8196;=&#8196;1 or 2) from the public catalogues and rejected 18 sources. We corrected the redshifts for 9 sources, typically faint [O&#8239;<span class=\"smallcaps\">II</span>] and Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters or sources in the redshift desert.</p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S18\"></a>3.7.2. SMACS2031</h4>\n<p>An early catalogue from the MUSE commissioning data taken on this cluster was presented in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R98\">Richard et al. (2015)</a> together with a cluster mass model. In view of the significant improvements in the data reduction since these observations were taken (see also <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R28\">Claeyssens et al. 2019</a>) we fully re-reduced and analysed the MUSE observations following our common process. We identify three additional multiply-imaged systems as faint Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters (forming a total of nine images), and also find two counterimages for existing systems. One published redshift has been corrected.</p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S19\"></a>3.7.3. MACS0416</h4>\n<p>A first analysis of the MUSE datasets in MACS0416 was presented by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R22\">Caminha et al. (2017a)</a> together with the CLASH/VLT redshifts from <a name=\"InR10\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R10\">Balestra et al. (2016)</a>. The data they analysed includes the full MUSE coverage in the southern part (MACS0416S, programme ID 094.A-0525) but only the GTO coverage in the northern part (MACS0416N, programme ID 094.A-0115). In the southern part, we find small redshift differences for five sources in common and at low confidence (<i>zconf</i>&#8198;&#8196;=&#8196;&#8198;1). One confirmed Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitter (CLASHVLTJ041608.03-240528.1 at <i>z</i>&#8198;&#8196;=&#8196;&#8198;4.848) was not detected with <tt>muselet</tt> in our catalogue but we confirmed it from the narrow-band cube at low confidence. In the same region, we identify nine new multiply-imaged systems producing 22 images in the MUSE data, which were not used in previous published models.</p>\n<p>In the northern part, the MUSE data used in our analysis is much deeper and we find no discrepancy for the sources in common with (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R22\">Caminha et al. 2017a</a>). <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R113\">Vanzella et al. (2021)</a> present one source at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;6.63 from the deep observations, which was also identified in our <tt>muselet</tt> catalogue. The deeper data provide us with additional redshifts (not used in previous published models) for 15 systems and 33 multiple images in that region, including 11 systems newly discovered with MUSE as faint Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters.</p>\n<p>Following the submission of this manuscript, <a name=\"InR112\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R112\">Vanzella et al. (2020)</a> presented an analysis of the same MACS0416 MUSE fields. They identify a counter-image for 6 multiply imaged systems in the north, which were not originally included in our analysis, and we confirm them in our extracted spectra at low to medium confidence level (<i>zconf</i>&#8196;=&#8196;1&#8722;2). In addition, they present one additional triply imaged system in the overlap region between the two MUSE fields, which we add in our catalogues for completeness as system 100. In comparison with their catalogue of multiple images, we confirm 16 additional multiply imaged systems with MUSE redshifts in our analysis, including 7 in the deep northern part.</p>\n<p>Finally, as in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S17\">3.7.1</a>, we cross-check the agreement between our redshift measurements and the GLASS catalogue from (<a name=\"InR52\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R52\">Hoag et al. 2016</a>) for the sources in common, and find no redshift discrepancies.</p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S20\"></a>3.7.4. MACS1206</h4>\n<p><a name=\"InR23\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R23\">Caminha et al. (2017b)</a> presented an analysis of the same MUSE data taken in the field of the cluster MACS1206 as in our sample. Their full spectroscopic catalogue is not publicly available but we have cross-checked the redshifts and multiply-imaged systems with our own analysis. We recover all of the systems at the same spectroscopic redshifts as used in their strong-lensing model. In addition, we identify eight new systems (named 29&#8211;36) of two to four images each (total 21 images) in our analysis of the datacubes. These 21 images are in their large majority Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters, generally diffuse and extended, that were found by <tt>muselet</tt>. The redshifts were further confirmed by predictions from the well-constrained lens model (rms<sub>model</sub>&#8196;=&#8196;0<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq19.gif\"></span>52).</p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S21\"></a>3.7.5. RXJ1347</h4>\n<p><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R24\">Caminha et al. (2019)</a> presented an analysis of early observations taken in the RXJ1347, restricted to the upper-left quadrant of the mosaic taken in WFM-NOAO-N. We compare our spectroscopic redshifts with the public catalogue available on VizieR, as well as the constraints presented in their lens model, based on 8 multiply-imaged systems including 4 with spectroscopic confirmation (totalling 9 images). All the published sources are in common with our spectroscopic catalogue and there are no redshift discrepancies. The full dataset on this cluster gives us a significant increase in the number of spectroscopic redshifts and multiple systems: we identify 25 additional systems with a spectropic redshift, producing a total of 119 images. We compared our sample with the public redshift catalogue from GLASS on this cluster and did not identify any discrepancies between common redshifts. We boosted the confidence level for 2 MUSE sources with matching lines with GLASS observations.</p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S22\"></a>3.7.6. MACS0329</h4>\n<p><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R24\">Caminha et al. (2019)</a> presented an analysis of the same MUSE data taken in the field of the cluster MACS0329. We compare our spectroscopic redshifts with the public catalogue available on VizieR, and identify one source at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;2.919 with diffuse Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emission which we did not detect in our <tt>muselet</tt> catalogue. We confirm from our lensing predictions that it is indeed a multiply imaged candidate associated with the halo of our <tt>muselet</tt> source 129 showing the same spectral line. We treat these images as a multiply-imaged candidate, but their precise location is too uncertain to be included as multiple images in our lensing model.</p>\n<p>In addition, we identify two clear pairs of multiply imaged Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters which we include as strong lensing constraints (our systems 4 and 7) but which were not used in the strong lensing model from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R24\">Caminha et al. (2019)</a>. In both cases, one image from the system was in common between the two spectroscopic catalogues. We also identify 11 low confidence (<i>zconf</i>&#8196;=&#8196;1) Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters not present in their catalogue, which either do not predict or for which we cannot rule out the presence of a counterimages, as well as a high confidence (<i>zconf</i>&#8196;=&#8196;3) [O&#8239;<span class=\"smallcaps\">II</span>] emitter at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;0.963.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S23\"></a>3.8. Spectral analysis</h3>\n<p>Due to their different physical origins, the spectral features identified in each source as part of the cross-correlation (e.g., K, H Ca lines in cluster members, nebular emission lines, ISM absorption lines, Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emission) or through manual redshift measurement do not provide uniform constraints on the accuracy and precision of the redshift estimates. In addition, the cross-correlation carried out by <tt>Marz</tt> can be systematically off, and the results do not provide us with a reliable error on the redshift measurement.</p>\n<p>Therefore, to properly distinguish between the various redshift estimates and get a better estimate on the redshift error, we make use of the P<span class=\"smallcaps\">YPLATEFIT</span> tool developed for the MUSE deep fields (Bacon et al., in prep.) on the weighted, sky-subtracted 1D spectra. P<span class=\"smallcaps\">YPLATEFIT</span> is a simplified python version of the original P<span class=\"smallcaps\">LATEFIT</span> IDL routines developed by <a name=\"InR107\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R107\">Tremonti et al. (2004)</a> and <a name=\"InR17\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R17\">Brinchmann et al. (2004)</a> for the SDSS project. It performs a global continuum fitting of the spectrum, and then fits individual emission and absorption lines using a Gaussian profile (or asymmetric Gaussian for the Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> line). Multiple redshift estimates are measured for each family of spectral features (nebular emission lines, Balmer absorption lines, Lyman-<i>&#945;</i>,&#8230;), allowing for small velocity offsets (within 150 km s<sup>&#8722;1</sup>, but up to 500 km s<sup>&#8722;1</sup> for Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emission).</p>\n<p>The line profile fitting is performed using the L<span class=\"smallcaps\">MFIT</span> python module. The best values and errors on the redshift and spectral line parameters (flux, signal-to-noise ratio, equivalent width) are computed using a bootstrap technique. Two examples of this spectral line fitting are presented in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F6\">6</a>.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F6\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 6.</span></a>\n<p>Examples of P<span class=\"smallcaps\">YPLATEFIT</span> spectral fitting, for two sources in our catalogues. <i>Top row</i> shows the case of the bright <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4.03 galaxy in MACS0940 (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R28\">Claeyssens et al. 2019</a>) with <i>zconf</i>&#8196;=&#8196;3 and the <i>bottom row</i> a <tt>MUSELET</tt>-selected galaxy at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;0.337 and <i>zconf</i>&#8196;=&#8196;2 in the same cluster field (M364). The <i>left panel</i> gives an overview of the spectrum, while the <i>middle and right panels</i> zoom in on specific spectral line fits. The best-fit spectrum and global continuum fit are plotted in red and blue, respectively.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div></p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S24\"></a>3.9. Full redshift catalogue</h3>\n<p>We provide a summary of all spectroscopic measurements for each cluster, in the form of two tables available at the CDS (examples for the first entries are presented in Tables <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T6\">A.1</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T7\">A.2</a>). A main table gives the relevant information for each source: location, redshift, and confidence, as well as photometric measurements, magnification, and multiple image identification. A companion table lists the measurements obtained by the P<span class=\"smallcaps\">YPLATEFIT</span> spectral fits for each source.</p>\n<p>Figure <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F7\">7</a> presents the spectroscopic catalogues overlaid on the colour HST images of each cluster, showing the spatial distribution of each redshift category with respect to the MUSE Fields as well as the region where we expect the multiple images.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F7\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7.</span></a>\n<p>Location of MUSE spectroscopic redshifts over HST F606W-F814W-F160W colour composites. North is up and east is left. The cyan dashed lines represent the limits of the MUSE datasets, while the solid white contour highlights the region where strongly-lensed multiple images are expected.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div></p>\n<p><a name=\"F8\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig8_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7.</span></a>\n<p>continued.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div></p>\n<p><a name=\"F9\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig9_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7.</span></a>\n<p>continued.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div></p>\n<p><a name=\"F10\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig10_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7.</span></a>\n<p>continued.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div></p>\n<p>Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T4\">4</a> summarises the redshift measurements both for all sources and for the high-confidence (<i>zconf</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;1) sources. There is a clear trend for clusters having shallower MUSE data (e.g., MACS0329, Bullet) to have a lower fraction of secure redshifts (<i>zconf</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;1). We present a redshift histogram for all sources in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F11\">8</a>, which is discussed further in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S28\">5</a>. Fourteen percent of all redshift measurements from the MUSE datacubes (and 12% of high confidence detections, with <i>zconf</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;1) are sources purely detected from their line emission with <tt>muselet</tt>, that is to say they cannot be securely associated with an HST source from the photometric catalogues. While the number of such <i>line-only</i> sources in the final catalogue strongly depends on the depth of the HST images (which varies from 26&#8211;29 AB for a point source depending on the field/filter), we have identified a few such sources even at the depth of the HST FF images (&#8764;29 AB). They correspond to high equivalent width Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters, comparable to sources discovered in the MUSE deep fields (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R8\">Bacon et al. 2017</a>; <a name=\"InR47\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R47\">Hashimoto et al. 2017</a>; <a name=\"InR80\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R80\">Maseda et al. 2018</a>). Low-redshift line-only sources are typically associated stripped gas and jellyfish galaxies in the clusters, or high equivalent width emission lines from compact galaxies.</p>\n<p><a name=\"T4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/T4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 4.</span></a>\n<p>Summary of all spectroscopic measurements.</p>\n</div></div></p>\n<p><a name=\"F11\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig11_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 8.</span></a>\n<p>Global redshift distribution of MUSE sources in the lensing cluster fields. <i>Left panel</i>: comparison between the overall distribution and sources with high confidence redshifts (<i>zconf</i>&#8196;=&#8196;2,&#8198;3), the latter before and after (&#8216;unique&#8217;) accounting for image multiplicity. <i>Right panel</i>: comparison between the overall distribution and the line-only sources (pure line emitters without any HST counterpart, see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S24\">3.9</a>).</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div></p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S25\"></a>4. Mass models</h2>\n<p>In order to interpret the measured spectrophotometric properties of lensed background sources in a more physical way, we must first account for (and correct) both the magnification factors and the general shape distortions that massive cluster cores impart to the observations. To do this, we generate parametric models of each cluster&#8217;s total mass distribution, using the numerous multiple images identified in the MUSE catalogues as constraints. In this section, we describe the procedure we use for this analysis, which is similar to the process employed by the CATS (Clusters As Telescopes) team to generate mass models of the FF clusters (e.g., <a name=\"InR97\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R97\">Richard et al. 2014</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R56\">Jauzac et al. 2014</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R57\">2015</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R58\">2016</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R68\">Lagattuta et al. 2017</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R69\">2019</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R78\">Mahler et al. 2018</a>) and makes use of the latest version (v7.1) of the public L<span class=\"smallcaps\">ENSTOOL</span> software<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#FN8\">6</a></sup> (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R64\">Kneib et al. 1996</a>; <a name=\"InR61\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R61\">Jullo et al. 2007</a>).</p>\n<p>To reduce uncertainty, we use the spatial positions of only high-confidence multiple-image systems as constraints for a given model. Specifically, we include systems that are either confirmed spectroscopically (having at least one image with a spectroscopic redshift; called gold systems), or bright HST sources without a spectroscopic redshift, but with an obvious, unambiguous lensing configuration, similar to the ones reported as silver systems in previous works. Here, gold and silver are based on the notation used in previous FF studies (e.g., <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R77\">Lotz et al. 2017</a>). We note that the vast majority of known systems will have new spectroscopic redshifts thanks to MUSE, so this limitation does not strongly bias the final model. In fact, this conservative approach allows us to reach a sufficient precision such that we can assess additional multiple images in the spectroscopic catalogues, as discussed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S15\">3.6</a>. We also make use of the preliminary mass models and known HST arcs from references listed in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T1\">1</a> as a starting point for our strong-lensing analysis.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S26\"></a>4.1. Model parametrisation</h3>\n<p>L<span class=\"smallcaps\">ENSTOOL</span> uses a Monte Carlo Markov chain (MCMC) to sample the posterior probability distribution of the model, expressed as a function of the likelihood defined in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R61\">Jullo et al. (2007)</a>. In practice, we minimise the distances in the image plane:</p>\n<p><a name=\"FD3\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><a name=\"img_eq20\"></a><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq20.gif\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(3)</span></span></p>\n<p>with <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq21.gif\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq22.gif\"></span> representing the observed and predicted vector positions of multiple image <i>j</i> in system <i>i</i>, respectively. Furthermore, <i>&#963;</i><sub>pos</sub> is a global error on the position of all multiple images, which we fix at 0<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq23.gif\"></span>5. This value corresponds to the typical uncertainty in reproducing the strongly-lensed images, which is affected by the presence of mass substructures within the cluster or along the line of sight (<a name=\"InR62\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R62\">Jullo et al. 2010</a>). The best model found (which minimises the <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup> value) also minimises the global rms between <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq24.gif\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq25.gif\"></span> (herafter rms<sub>model</sub>).</p>\n<p>In order to estimate all the values of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq26.gif\"></span>, L<span class=\"smallcaps\">ENSTOOL</span> inverts the lens equation with a parametric potential which we assume to be a combination of double Pseudo Isothermal Elliptical mass profiles (dPIE, <a name=\"InR39\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R39\">El&#237;asd&#243;ttir et al. 2007</a>; <a name=\"InR106\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R106\">Suyu &amp; Halkola 2010</a>). dPIE potentials are isothermal profiles which are characterised by a central velocity dispersion <i>&#963;</i><sub>0</sub> and include a core radius <i>r</i><sub>core</sub> (producing a flattening of the mass distribution at the centre), and a cut radius <i>r</i><sub>cut</sub> (producing a drop-off of the mass distribution on large scales). Together with the central position (<i>x</i><sub>c</sub>, <i>y</i><sub>c</sub>) and elliptical shape (ellipticity <i>e</i>, angle <i>&#952;</i>), dPIE potentials are fully-defined by 7 parameters.</p>\n<p>For each cluster, we include a small number of cluster-scale dPIE profiles (up to three) to account for the smooth large-scale components of the mass distribution. Additionally, we assign individual dPIE potentials to each cluster member, which represent the galaxy-scale substructure. We fix the cut radius of cluster-scale mass components to 1 Mpc (e.g., <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R75\">Limousin et al. 2007</a>), as it is generally unconstrained by strong lensing, but allow the other parameters to vary freely in the fit.</p>\n<p>Cluster members used as galaxy-scale potentials are selected through the red sequence of elliptical galaxies, which is well-identified in a colour-magnitude diagram based on the HST photometry. More details on this selection are provided in, for instance, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R97\">Richard et al. (2014)</a> for the FF clusters. For the newest lens models and most recent HST observations, we make use of the <i>F</i>606<i>W</i>&#8211;<i>F</i>814<i>W</i> vs. <i>F</i>160<i>W</i> colour-magnitude diagram to select cluster members down to 0.01 <i>L</i><sup>*</sup>, where <i>L</i><sup>*</sup> is the characteristic luminosity at the cluster redshift based on the luminosity function from <a name=\"InR76\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R76\">Lin et al. (2006)</a>. As a further refinement to this process, we cross-check the selected members with existing redshifts in our MUSE spectroscopic catalogue.</p>\n<p>To reduce the number of free parameters in the model, we assume that the shape parameters (<i>x</i><sub>c</sub>,&#8198;<i>y</i><sub>c</sub>,&#8198;<i>e</i>,&#8198;<i>&#952;</i>) of the galaxy-scale potentials follow the shape of their light distribution, and use the following scaling relations on the dPIE parameters with respect to their luminosity <i>L</i>:</p>\n<p><a name=\"FD4\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><a name=\"img_eq27\"></a><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq27.gif\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(4)</span></span></p>\n<p>which follow from the <a name=\"InR41\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R41\">Faber &amp; Jackson (1976)</a> relation of elliptical galaxies and the assumption of a constant mass-to-light ratio. The fixed value for <i>r</i><sub>core</sub> is negligible and follows from the discussion in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R75\">Limousin et al. (2007)</a>.</p>\n<p>The mass models are constructed through an iterative process, using a single cluster-scale dPIE profile at first to fit the most confident sets of multiply imaged systems. Other systems are tested and included as additional constraints, and a second or third cluster-scale dPIE profile is added when it has a significant effect in reducing rms<sub>model</sub>. While most galaxy-scale mass components follow the general scaling relations presented in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#FD4\">4</a>), we do fit the mass parameters of some individual galaxies separately, in special cases where we can constrain these values using additional information outside of the scaling relation. This is particularly the case for (a) BCGs, which are known not to follow the usual scaling relations of elliptical galaxies, (b) cluster members lying very close (&#8818;5&#8243;) to multiple images, which locally influence their location (and sometimes produce galaxy-galaxy lens systems), and (c) additional galaxies located slightly in the foreground or background of the cluster, which produce a local lensing effect on their surroundings but will not follow the same scaling relations.</p>\n<p>Finally, for the most complex clusters (A370, MACS1206, RXJ1347) we have tested the addition of an external shear potential. Typically used when modelling galaxy-galaxy lensed systems (e.g., <a name=\"InR32\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R32\">Desprez et al. 2018</a>), this potential accounts for an unknown effect of the large scale mass environment surrounding the cluster, in the form of a constant shear <i>&#947;</i><sub>ext</sub> at an angle &#934;<sub>ext</sub>. However it does not bring any additional mass to the model (see also the discussions in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R78\">Mahler et al. 2018</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R69\">Lagattuta et al. 2019</a>).</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S27\"></a>4.2. Results of the strong lensing analysis</h3>\n<p>In Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T5\">5</a>, we summarise the number of strong-lensing constraints (systems and images) which were confirmed by our strong lensing analysis for each cluster, along with the rms from the best fit models. The complete list of multiple images and the best-fit parameters of the mass models are detailed in Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#APP2\">B</a>.</p>\n<p><a name=\"T5\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/T5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 5.</span></a>\n<p>Global cluster properties measured from our strong lensing mass model.</p>\n</div></div></p>\n<p>Overall, these models are among the most constrained (in terms of number of independent multiply imaged systems) strong-lensing cluster cores to date. We stress that this occurs not only for clusters with deep HST imaging, such as those available in the FFs, but even clusters in our sample observed with snapshot HST images are densely constrained; for example, MACS0257 has 25 systems with spectroscopic redshifts, producing 81 total multiple images over a single 1 arcmin<sup>2</sup> MUSE field. This is entirely dominated by the population of multiply-imaged Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters, which are very faint in HST but are easily revealed by the MUSE IFU.</p>\n<p>Such a high density of constraints allows for a precise measurement of the mass profile, with a typical statistical error of &lt; 1% (e.g., <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R56\">Jauzac et al. 2014</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R24\">Caminha et al. 2019</a>). The improvement is typically a factor of &#8764;5 with respect to the models prior to MUSE observations (e.g., <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R98\">Richard et al. 2015</a>). This has many applications, allowing us for example to test different parametrisations of the mass models and line of sight effects (e.g., <a name=\"InR26\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R26\">Chiriv&#236; et al. 2018</a>) to improve the rms<sub>model</sub> even further and reduce systematics. Some discussion on these effects were presented for the clusters Abell 2744 and Abell 370 in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R78\">Mahler et al. (2018)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R69\">Lagattuta et al. (2019)</a>, respectively. One route to improve the models further is to combine the parametric mass models with a non-parametric (grid-like) mass distribution using a perturbative approach (<a name=\"InR12\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R12\">Beauchesne et al. 2020</a>).</p>\n<p>Another application of these very-constrained models is to make use of the high density of constraints at the centre of the cluster, and probe the inner slope of the mass distribution to test predictions from &#923;-CDM simulations (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R24\">Caminha et al. 2019</a>). Several clusters in our sample show so-called &#8216;hyperbolic-umbilic&#8217; lensing configurations (<a name=\"InR83\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R83\">Orban de Xivry &amp; Marshall 2009</a>), which are rarely seen and provide us with very important constraints in the cluster core (<a name=\"InR95\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R95\">Richard et al. 2009</a>). Finally, multiply-imaged systems appearing in the same regions of the cluster but originating from very different source plane redshifts are important for strong-lensing cosmography studies (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R62\">Jullo et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR20\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R20\">Caminha et al. 2016a</a>; <a name=\"InR2\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R2\">Acebron et al. 2017</a>).</p>\n<p>A full discussion of the 2D mass distribution of individual clusters is beyond the scope of this paper. However, in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T5\">5</a> we provide the main cluster parameters derived from our lens model which characterise their lensing power: namely the equivalent Einstein radius <i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub> at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4 (defined from the area within the critical curve &#931;, as <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq28.gif\"></span>), and the enclosed projected mass within this radius <i>M</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>&#952;</i><sub>E</sub>. We selected <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4 as it is the average DLS/DS (the lensing efficiency factor, ratio of the distance between the lens and the source over the distance to the source) for Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters which contribute to the majority of constraints.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S28\"></a>5. Source properties</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S29\"></a>5.1. Redshift distribution</h3>\n<p>The complete spectroscopic dataset of the 12 clusters amount to more than 3200 high-confidence redshifts, consisting of galaxies either in the foreground, in the cluster itself, or in the background. Overall, cluster members dominate the redshift distribution; this is clearly apparent in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T4\">4</a>, where cluster members account for &#8764;40% of the total spectroscopic sample. We display a histogram of the global redshift distribution combining all clusters in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F11\">8</a>. The left panel shows the distribution of all and high confidence redshifts when limited to unique sources, that is to say removing the additional images of strongly lensed systems. The right panel shows the distribution of line-only sources (i.e. sources detected purely from line emission without any HST counterpart).</p>\n<p>These histograms reveal a number of important features in the data, both intrinsic to our sample and unique to the MUSE instrument. Notably, since all of the clusters are located within a relatively narrow redshift range, there is a prominent peak around <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;0.4 representing the cluster overdensities. At the same time, we see that multiply imaged lensed sources start to represent a significant fraction (37%) of all galaxies at <i>z</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;1.8, as evidenced by the increasing discrepancy between the &#8220;all&#8221; (grey) and &#8220;unique&#8221; (purple) distributions in the left panel. Furthermore, the MUSE redshift desert (1.5&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>z</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;2.9), a region where no strong emission emission lines ([O&#8239;<span class=\"smallcaps\">II</span>], Lyman-<i>&#945;</i>) are present in the MUSE wavelength range, is also clearly visible, with a significant deficit of redshifts (especially for line-only sources) in those bins. Finally, the redshift histogram at <i>z</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;2.9 is dominated by the population of Lyman&#8722;<i>&#945;</i> emitters, which are more easily detected between sky lines. This produces small gaps in the redshift distribution at wavelengths where the sky is brighter, in particular at <i>z</i>&#8196;&#8764;&#8196;4.6 and <i>z</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;5.8.</p>\n<p>Compared to the total redshift histograms, individual clusters tend to show more prominent peaks at specific redshifts. This is a known effect of galaxy clustering in the small area probed behind lensing clusters (e.g., <a name=\"InR65\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R65\">Kneib et al. 2004</a>). Specific group-like structures are seen at <i>z</i>&#8196;&#8764;&#8196;4 behind Abell 2744 (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R78\">Mahler et al. 2018</a>) and <i>z</i>&#8196;&#8764;&#8196;1 behind Abell 370 (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R69\">Lagattuta et al. 2019</a>).</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S30\"></a>5.2. Kinematics of the cluster cores</h3>\n<p>The high velocities of galaxies in cluster cores appear clearly in the redshift distribution when zooming-in around the systemic cluster redshift (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F12\">9</a>). The shape of the distribution generally follows a single normal distribution, with the exception of Abell 2744 showing a clear bimodal distribution. For that particular cluster, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R78\">Mahler et al. (2018)</a> demonstrated that the two velocity components seen in the inner 400 kpc radius persist out to much larger distances, as they are associated (and in good agreement) with sparser spectroscopic data covering &gt; 1 Mpc scales (<a name=\"InR84\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R84\">Owers et al. 2011</a>).</p>\n<p><a name=\"F12\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F12.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig12_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F12.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 9.</span></a>\n<p><i>Left panel</i>: velocity distribution of cluster members for each of the 12 fields. The red curves shows the best fit Gaussian model of the distribution (2 Gaussian components in Abell 2744). <i>Right panel</i>: comparison between the total velocity dispersion from the dPIE profiles in the mass model and the total velocity dispersion from the velocity distribution. The square symbols mark the three clusters with only partial MUSE coverage in the cluster cores.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div></p>\n<p>Although a full analysis of the cluster kinematics is clearly limited by the spatial coverage of MUSE-only spectroscopy in the cluster core, the large number of cluster redshifts measured in the very central core (<i>R</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;300 kpc) still provides insight into the overall velocity dispersion in the different cluster components seen in the distribution. We fit either 1 or 2 Gaussian components per cluster to the velocity distribution and estimate the global velocity dispersion <i>&#963;</i><sub>dynamics</sub> as the quadratic sum of their <i>&#963;</i>. We independently estimate a global velocity dispersion <i>&#963;</i><sub>model</sub> from our strong lensing model, by taking the quadratic sum of the <i>&#963;</i><sub>0</sub> parameters in the cluster-scale dPIE components. We include a 1.3&#215; correction factor between the line-of-sight velocity dispersion and the dPIE <i>&#963;</i><sub>0</sub> parameters, as discussed in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R39\">El&#237;asd&#243;ttir et al. (2007)</a> for the typical values of core and cut radii in our cluster potentials.</p>\n<p>Figure <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F12\">9</a> (right panel) directly compares the two velocity dispersion estimators for the 12 clusters. Taken at face value, we find that the clusters span a large range in <i>&#963;</i>, but there is a generally good agreement between the two estimators for most of the clusters. This shows that despite the strong differences in the dynamical state of the clusters, the mass components included in our mass models account for a similar amount of mass as seen in the cluster velocity distribution, although we cannot directly associate between the large-scale clumps of the lens model and the velocity components. We observe a large dispersion on <i>&#963;</i><sub>dynamics</sub>, which is certainly due to the limited coverage of the velocity measurements and line-of-sight projection effects due to the overall geometry of the cluster. Moreover, clusters showing very high <i>&#963;</i><sub>dynamics</sub> (close to &#8764;2000 km s<sup>&#8722;1</sup>, as for Abell 370 and MACS1206) are most likely formed of multiple lower <i>&#963;</i> components which we cannot isolate individually. RXJ1347 is the most discrepant point in this diagram, with <i>&#963;</i><sub>dynamics</sub>&#8196;&#8764;&#8196;1100 km s<sup>&#8722;1</sup> despite it having the largest mass of the sample within its Einstein radius. This could be explained if multiple cluster structures are present with a low velocity difference, enhancing its lensing power while maintaining a low <i>&#963;</i><sub>dynamics</sub>. Regardless, we find an average ratio &#10216;<i>&#963;</i><sub>dynamics</sub>/<i>&#963;</i><sub>model</sub>&#10217; = 0.92 &#177; 0.14. Even though the cluster dynamics only probe the inner regions (&lt;200 kpc), we do not see a significant under- or overestimation of the global velocity dispersion in the velocity measurements.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S31\"></a>5.3. Magnification distribution and survey volume at high redshift</h3>\n<p>One of the direct outputs of the mass models is an estimate of the magnification factor at a given source redshift and image position. These values are crucial in order to correct absolute physical measurements of lensed sources, such as the stellar mass, luminosity, and star-formation rate, etc. We include this estimated magnification <i>&#956;</i> at the central location of each source in the spectroscopic catalogue (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T6\">A.1</a>). These values are generally well-constrained within the multiply imaged regions, but tend to be overestimated in the vicinity of the critical lines (typically <i>&#956;</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;25), where the emergence of lensed pairs and the resolved sources limit very strong magnification factors.</p>\n<p>We present the magnification distribution of the full set of lensed images in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F13\">10</a>, where we count the magnification of each observed image individually (i.e., multiply-imaged systems are not combined into a single entry). The minimum magnification is set by the limits of the MUSE coverage in each cluster, but is typically <i>&#956;</i>&#8196;&#8764;&#8196;1.5&#8722;2. The distribution <i>N</i>(<i>&#956;</i>) at <i>&#956;</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;2 follows a clear power-law, with an exponent <i>&#956;</i><sup>&#8722;2.02&#8197;&#177;&#8197;0.09</sup>. This value is very close to the theoretical prediction of optical depth for strong lensing magnification, <i>&#964;</i>&#8196;&#8733;&#8196;<i>&#956;</i><sup>&#8722;2</sup> (<a name=\"InR16\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R16\">Blandford &amp; Narayan 1986</a>) in the case of smooth mass distributions like the ones used in our modelling. This shows that our detection process of MUSE lensed sources is not strongly affected and missing additional sources at very high magnifications.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F13\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig13_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 10.</span></a>\n<p>Magnification distribution for all background sources. We overlay a theoretical <i>&#956;</i><sup>&#8722;2</sup> relation to guide the eye. We observe a significant drop in the number of sources at low magnifications (<i>&#956;</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;1.5), due to the limits set by the FoV of the MUSE observations, and at very high magnifications (<i>&#956;</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;25) due to the very small statistics and possibly the resolved nature of Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div></p>\n<p>Another important measurement we derive from the lens model is the equivalent source-plane area covered by the MUSE observations. This differs from the image-plane area (i.e., the MUSE footprint) due to the strong lensing effect, with the effective source-plane area reduced by the same amount as the magnification factor; unsurprisingly this also diminishes the associated survey volume behind the cluster. Figure <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F14\">11</a> presents the source-plane area for each cluster at a typical source redshift <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4, with the colourscale representing the greatest magnification factor at a given source position (recall that sources lying within the multiply-imaged region will have more than one magnification solution). In the figure, the strongly lensed region itself appears in the form of the caustic lines in the source plane.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F14\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig14_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 11.</span></a>\n<p><i>Left panel</i>: source plane coverage of each cluster at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4, as a function of the strong lensing magnification of the most magnified image. The black square shows a 1 arcmin<sup>2</sup> for scale. <i>Right panel</i>: effective volume surveyed at 2.9&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>z</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;6.7 with MUSE for Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters, as a function of the magnification of the brightest image. Presented are individual volumes behind each cluster and the total over all fields.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div></p>\n<p>Compared to the total observed area of &#8764;23.5 arcmin<sup>2</sup> on sky covered with MUSE, the total effective area covered in the source plane at high redshift is 4 arcmin<sup>2</sup>, a factor 6&#215; smaller. From these source plane areas we compute the effective volume covered at source redshifts 2.9&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>z</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;6.7 when detecting lensed Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters, as a function of lensing magnification. This is important knowledge when probing the luminosity function of Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters behind clusters (<a name=\"InR15\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R15\">Bina et al. 2016</a>; <a name=\"InR31\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R31\">de La Vieuville et al. 2019</a>) compared to blank fields (<a name=\"InR33\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R33\">Drake et al. 2017</a>; <a name=\"InR49\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R49\">Herenz et al. 2019</a>). We stress that there are strong cluster-to-cluster variations in the volume surveyed depending on the geometry of the caustics and the MUSE coverage, with a maximum volume ranging between 600 and 10 000 comoving Mpc<sup>3</sup> in individual clusters at any magnification. While a full volume computation would require more precise completeness measurements accounting for spatial variations of exposure time and the evolution of the noise as a function of wavelength, these variations can easily explain the cluster-to-cluster differences in the observed number counts of LAEs, as found by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R31\">de La Vieuville et al. (2019)</a>.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S32\"></a>5.4. Resolved properties of high redshift galaxies</h3>\n<p>Despite the effective surface reduction in the source plane, one of the strong benefits from the magnification is to increase the apparent size of lensed galaxies, allowing us to reach much smaller intrinsic scales. Combined with MUSE integral field spectroscopy, this magnification gives access to resolved spectral properties in particular from the nebular line emission. Some of the brightest and most extended arcs at 0.5&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>z</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;1.5 in the present sample have been studied in <a name=\"InR87\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R87\">Patr&#237;cio et al. (2018)</a> to measure the detailed gas kinematics at sub-kpc scales, in relation with the presence of star-forming clumps and significant resolved metallicity gradients as a function of radius (<a name=\"InR88\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R88\">Patr&#237;cio et al. 2019</a>). These bright extended arcs are rare cases of very strong magnification in typical <i>L</i><sup>*</sup> galaxies. But the measurement of resolved kinematics can be pushed to fainter masses/luminosities and larger samples to study the Tully-Fisher relation and morpho-kinematics of lensed sources reconstructed in the source plane. This allows spatially resolved analyses which are complementary to blank field studies, the latter being more strongly limited by the spatial resolution (<a name=\"InR30\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R30\">Contini et al. 2016</a>; <a name=\"InR44\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R44\">Girard et al. 2020</a>; <a name=\"InR1\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R1\">Abril-Melgarejo et al. 2021</a>).</p>\n<p>At higher redshifts (<i>z</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;2.9) IFU observations have now established that the Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emission of distant galaxies is typically more spatially extended than the stellar UV continuum, illuminating the surrounding circumgalactic medium (<a name=\"InR116\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R116\">Wisotzki et al. 2016</a>; <a name=\"InR71\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R71\">Leclercq et al. 2017</a>). The origin of this Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emission is complex, and only the brightest Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> haloes are sufficiently extended to allow spatially resolved analyses in the absence of any lensing effect (<a name=\"InR40\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R40\">Erb et al. 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR72\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R72\">Leclercq et al. 2020</a>) and test predictions from simulations.</p>\n<p>MUSE observations on lensing clusters offer the power to identify extended gas around high redshift galaxies (once magnified), allowing detailed studies of the spectral line properties within multiple regions, in particular through bright Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> extended haloes (<a name=\"InR86\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R86\">Patr&#237;cio et al. 2016</a>; <a name=\"InR103\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R103\">Smit et al. 2017</a>; <a name=\"InR21\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R21\">Caminha et al. 2016b</a>; <a name=\"InR111\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R111\">Vanzella et al. 2017</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R28\">Claeyssens et al. 2019</a>). Figure <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F15\">12</a> shows a very clear example taken from our sample of extended emission detected over the <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4.086 source originally identified by <a name=\"InR29\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R29\">Cohen &amp; Kneib (2002)</a> in RXJ1347. This galaxy appears as a very compact source in the HST image (<i>FWHM</i> &lt; 0<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq29.gif\"></span>3, limited by the PSF), while the Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emission reaches an extension of 13&#8243; in the form of an arc. The critical line at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4.086 straddles the arc at the location of the UV source, which appears as a bright H&#8239;<span class=\"smallcaps\">II</span> knot coincidentally located over the caustic line in the source plane. This example illustrates the capability of MUSE observations to clearly disentangle between stellar and nebular emission at these high redshifts. We identified 2&#8211;3 such magnified (spanning &gt; 5&#8243;) Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters per cluster, for which we will be able to retrieve detailed physical properties at scales better than typically &#8764;1 kpc (Claeyssens et al., in prep.).</p>\n<p><a name=\"F15\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F15.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig15_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F15.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 12.</span></a>\n<p>Example of very extended Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitter in RXJ1347 (system 25), at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4.086. <i>Left panel</i> shows the HST colour image and the <i>right panel</i> the MUSE NB image around the Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emission. White dashed contours of the NB are overlayed on HST. The red curve shows the critical line at this redshift, which crosses the arc-shaped Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emission at the location of a point-like source in HST.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div></p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S33\"></a>6. Summary and conclusion</h2>\n<p>We have presented a spectroscopic survey of MUSE/VLT observations towards 12 massive clusters selected from the MACS, CLASH, and FF samples. The data represent &#8764;23 arcmin<sup>2</sup> on sky as single pointings or mosaics, with an effective exposure time ranging between 2 and 15 h and a grand total of &gt; 125 h.</p>\n<p>Thanks to improvements in the data reduction and the tools developed for source detection and inspection in the datacubes, our final spectroscopic catalogue presents &gt; 3200 spectroscopic redshifts with high confidence (<i>zconf</i>&#8196;=&#8196;2 or 3). Improvements include careful self-calibration and specific masking to remove instrumental systematics and other artefacts in the datacube, a better estimate of the noise properties, and the establishment of a clear process for spectral analysis.</p>\n<p>Deep (&gt; 8 h per pointing) MUSE observations reveal a very high density of faint lensed LAEs, which dominate the population of background galaxies with spectroscopic redshifts. A very significant fraction of high-redshift galaxies are multiply-imaged systems, which we use to precisely constrain mass models in the cluster cores. The number of strong lensing constraints in a single cluster, reaching 70 systems producing 189 multiple images in the case of MACS0416, and the fraction of spectroscopically confirmed images (&gt; 90% in the models used in our analysis) are among the highest in any known cluster including the FFs. These parametric mass models are fully included in our redshift assessment process to help confirm or reject some multiple images.</p>\n<p>Based on our cluster mass models, we assess the source plane survey area at high redshift (<i>z</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;3) and find that the effective surface area is &#8764;6 arcmin<sup>2</sup>, a factor of 6 smaller than in the image plane due to the lensing magnification. This shows that the number density of LAEs is very high at the low luminosities probed through lensing magnification. The magnification distribution <i>N</i>(<i>&#956;</i>) is compatible with the theoretical predictions in the very strong magnification regime (2&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>&#956;</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;25), showing that our detection process for lensed sources is not missing additional sources in the high magnification regime. We note that, in the area covered by MUSE observations, multiple images dominate the detected sources at <i>z</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;1.8, while the fraction of multiple images is much lower at <i>z</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;1.5 (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F11\">8</a>). This difference is related to the magnification bias (<a name=\"InR18\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R18\">Broadhurst et al. 1995</a>), which affects the source populations differently depending on the redshift and therefore intrinsic luminosity. The redshift range 1.8&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>z</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;6.7 is therefore ideal to identify a large number of multiply imaged sources and makes MUSE very efficient for this purpose at 3&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>z</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;6.7. The future BlueMUSE instrument (<a name=\"InR99\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R99\">Richard et al. 2019</a>) will complement this redshift range by targetting LAEs at 1.9&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>z</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;4, where the density of multiply-imaged LAEs is expected to be very high.</p>\n<p>We make the results of this analysis publicly available in the form of a first data release<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#FN9\">7</a></sup>, including the reduced datacubes, spectrophotometric catalogues, extracted spectra, and mass models. Additional MUSE observations of lensing clusters taken under the GTO programme and archival observations (including lower redshift clusters such as Abell 1689, 2390 and 2667) will be inspected in a similar manner and their data released in subsequent catalogues. Overall, this very rich dataset has a strong legacy value, allowing for a large variety of statistical studies from cluster physics to very high redshift galaxies. The sample of magnified Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters will be particularly suitable for follow-ups at longer wavelengths with the <i>James Webb</i> Space Telescope (JWST) and the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) to better constrain the resolved star formation and clump properties through ISM diagnostics.</p>\n<hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN3\"></a><sup>1</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"https://archive.stsci.edu/missions/hlsp/clash/\" target=\"_blank\">https://archive.stsci.edu/missions/hlsp/clash/</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN4\"></a><sup>2</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"https://archive.stsci.edu/missions/hlsp/frontier/\" target=\"_blank\">https://archive.stsci.edu/missions/hlsp/frontier/</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN5\"></a><sup>3</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"https://www.eso.org/sci/software/pipelines/muse/\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.eso.org/sci/software/pipelines/muse/</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN6\"></a><sup>4</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"https://mpdaf.readthedocs.io/en/latest/\" target=\"_blank\">https://mpdaf.readthedocs.io/en/latest/</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN7\"></a><sup>5</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"http://montage.ipac.caltech.edu/\" target=\"_blank\">http://montage.ipac.caltech.edu/</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN8\"></a><sup>6</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Publicly available at:</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://git-cral.univ-lyon1.fr/lenstool/lenstool\" target=\"_blank\">https://git-cral.univ-lyon1.fr/lenstool/lenstool</a>,</p>\n<p>more details at:</p>\n<p><a href=\"https://projets.lam.fr/projects/lenstool/wiki/\" target=\"_blank\">https://projets.lam.fr/projects/lenstool/wiki/</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN9\"></a><sup>7</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"https://cral-perso.univ-lyon1.fr/labo/perso/johan.richard/MUSE_data_release/\" <tt><a href=\"https://archive.stsci.edu/prepds/frontier/lensmodels/\" target=\"_blank\">https://archive.stsci.edu/prepds/frontier/lensmodels/</a></tt></p>\n</div></div>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a This research has made use of the VizieR catalogue access tool, CDS, Strasbourg, France. The original description of the VizieR service was published in A&amp;AS 143, 23. This research made use of M<span class=\"smallcaps\">ONTAGE</span>. It is funded by the National Science Foundation under Grant Number ACI-1440620, and was previously funded by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration&#8217;s Earth Science Technology Office, Computation Technologies Project, under Cooperative Agreement Number NCC5-626 between NASA and the California Institute of Technology.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"ref\"></a>References</h2>\n    <div id=\"content\">\n        <ol class=\"references\">\n                    <li>\n                <a name=\"R1\"></a>Abril-Melgarejo, V., Epinat, B., Mercier, W., et al. 2021, A&amp;A, in press [<a href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/2101.08069\" target=\"_blank\">arXiv: 2101.08069</a>]\n\n                \n\t\t                \t\t\n                \n                                    <a href=\"https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?author=Abril-Melgarejo%2C+V.%2C+Epinat%2C+B.%2C+Mercier%2C+W.&journal=A%26A&publication_year=2021\">[Google&nbsp;Scholar]</a>\n                \n                \n                 <span class=\"Z3988\" title=\"\">\n                                    </span>\n\n                \n                            </li>\n                    <li>\n                <a name=\"R2\"></a>Acebron, A., Jullo, E., Limousin, M., et al. 2017, MNRAS, 470, 1809\n\n                \n\t\t                \t\t\n                \n                                    <a href=\"https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?author=Acebron%2C+A.%2C+Jullo%2C+E.%2C+Limousin%2C+M.&journal=MNRAS&volume=470&pages=1809&publication_year=2017\">[Google&nbsp;Scholar]</a>\n                \n                \n                 <span class=\"Z3988\" title=\"\">\n                                    </span>\n\n                \n                            </li>\n                    <li>\n                <a name=\"R3\"></a>Astropy Collaboration (Robitaille, T.                <a    \n                \n                 <span class=\"Z3988\" title=\"\">\n                                    </span>\n\n                \n                            </li>\n                </ol>\n    </div>\n\n\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"app\"></a>Appendix A:  Description of spectroscopic catalogues</h2>\n<p><a name=\"T6\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/T6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table A.1.</span></a>\n<p>Example entries of the spectroscopic table for the two sources presented in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F6\">6</a>.</p>\n</div></div></p>\n<p><a name=\"T7\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/T7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table A.2.</span></a>\n<p>Example entries of the spectroscopic lines table, for the same sources as Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T6\">A.1</a>.</p>\n</div></div></p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"app\"></a>Appendix B:  Mass model parameters and multiple images</h2>\n<p>We present for all new mass models the best fit parameters from Lenstool in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T8\">B.1</a> and the list of constraints used in Tables <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T9\">B.2</a>&#8211;<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T17\">B.10</a>. Figure <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F16\">B.1</a> mark these multiply imaged systems over the HST colour image in each cluster. A full description of the Abell 2744 and Abell 370 mass models has been provided in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R78\">Mahler et al. (2018)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R69\">Lagattuta et al. (2019)</a> respectively, and they were released as v4 of the Clusters As Telescopes (CATs) in the Frontier Field mass models<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#FN10\">8</a></sup>. The new MACS0416 model is very similar to v4 of the CATS model available on the same page.</p>\n<p><a name=\"T8\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/T8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table B.1.</span></a>\n<p>Best fit model parameters for the mass distribution in each cluster.</p>\n</div></div></p>\n<p><a name=\"F16\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F16.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig16_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F16.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. B.1.</span></a>\n<p>Overview of all multiply-imaged systems used in the strong-lensing model of MACS0257. The cyan dashed line highlights the limits of the MUSE observations. The white line represents the limit of the region where we expect multiples images. The red line delineates the critical line for a source at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div></p>\n<p><a name=\"F17\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F17.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig17_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F17.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. B.1.</span></a>\n<p>continued.
