class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1.</span></a>\n<p>MUSE exposure maps overlayed on top of the HST/<i>F</i>814<i>W</i> images. The 12 clusters from Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T1\">1</a> are displayed in reading order, with the reference position from the same table marked as a white cross.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F1\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2.</span></a>\n<p>Effect of auto-calibration on the white light image (example shown for MACS0940). <i>From left to right</i>: without auto-calibration, using auto-calibration with tuned object masks, with additional interstack masks. See Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S7\">2.5</a> for more details.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F2\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3.</span></a>\n<p>5<i>&#963;</i> continuum flux limit estimated in empty sky region of the MACS0940 datacube (8 h exposure time), including (orange curve) or not (blue curve) the correction for correlated noise. The increased noise level within the AO filter (around 5890 Angstroms) is due to the shorter effective exposure time in WFM-NOAO-N instrument mode (50 min).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F3\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4.</span></a>\n<p>Flowchart presenting the process of building the MUSE spectrophotometric catalogues, based on the input HST images and MUSE datacube. Section <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S9\">3</a> presents each step of the procedure in detail.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F4\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5.</span></a>\n<p>Example of faint Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emission (large yellow circle) detected near the position of the predicted counterimage from <tt>muselet</tt> source 641 in cluster MACS0329, at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;6.011 (small white circle). The image shows a smoothed narrow-band image at the peak wavelength of the emission. The dotted ellipse denotes the estimated 1-<i>&#963;</i> error region of the predicted location.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F5\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 6.</span></a>\n<p>Examples of P<span class=\"smallcaps\">YPLATEFIT</span> spectral fitting, for two sources in our catalogues. <i>Top row</i> shows the case of the bright <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4.03 galaxy in MACS0940 (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R28\">Claeyssens et al. 2019</a>) with <i>zconf</i>&#8196;=&#8196;3 and the <i>bottom row</i> a <tt>MUSELET</tt>-selected galaxy at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;0.337 and <i>zconf</i>&#8196;=&#8196;2 in the same cluster field (M364). The <i>left panel</i> gives an overview of the spectrum, while the <i>middle and right panels</i> zoom in on specific spectral line fits. The best-fit spectrum and global continuum fit are plotted in red and blue, respectively.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F6\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7.</span></a>\n<p>Location of MUSE spectroscopic redshifts over HST F606W-F814W-F160W colour composites. North is up and east is left. The cyan dashed lines represent the limits of the MUSE datasets, while the solid white contour highlights the region where strongly-lensed multiple images are expected.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F12.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 9.</span></a>\n<p><i>Left panel</i>: velocity distribution of cluster members for each of the 12 fields. The red curves shows the best fit Gaussian model of the distribution (2 Gaussian components in Abell 2744). <i>Right panel</i>: comparison between the total velocity dispersion from the dPIE profiles in the mass model and the total velocity dispersion from the velocity distribution. The square symbols mark the three clusters with only partial MUSE coverage in the cluster cores.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F12\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig13_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 10.</span></a>\n<p>Magnification distribution for all background sources. We overlay a theoretical <i>&#956;</i><sup>&#8722;2</sup> relation to guide the eye. We observe a significant drop in the number of sources at low magnifications (<i>&#956;</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;1.5), due to the limits set by the FoV of the MUSE observations, and at very high magnifications (<i>&#956;</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;25) due to the very small statistics and possibly the resolved nature of Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F13\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig14_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 11.</span></a>\n<p><i>Left panel</i>: source plane coverage of each cluster at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4, as a function of the strong lensing magnification of the most magnified image. The black square shows a 1 arcmin<sup>2</sup> for scale. <i>Right panel</i>: effective volume surveyed at 2.9&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>z</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;6.7 with MUSE for Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters, as a function of the magnification of the brightest image. Presented are individual volumes behind each cluster and the total over all fields.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F14\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F15.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig15_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F15.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 12.</span></a>\n<p>Example of very extended Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitter in RXJ1347 (system 25), at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4.086. <i>Left panel</i> shows the HST colour image and the <i>right panel</i> the MUSE NB image around the Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emission. White dashed contours of the NB are overlayed on HST. The red curve shows the critical line at this redshift, which crosses the arc-shaped Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emission at the location of a point-like source in HST.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F15\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F16.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig16_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F16.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. B.1.</span></a>\n<p>Overview of all multiply-imaged systems used in the strong-lensing model of MACS0257. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico ico-info\"></span>\n\t\t<div>\n\t\t\t<p>Initial download of the metrics may take a while.</p>\n\t\t</div>\n\t</div>\n\n\n</div>\n\n\n\n\n</div>\n<script type=\"text/javascript\" src=\"/templates/source/js/metrics-tab.js\"></script>\n\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\n                                                    </div>\n                        <nav class=\"article\">\n name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Univ Lyon, Univ Lyon1, ENS de Lyon, CNRS, Centre de Recherche Astrophysique de Lyon UMR5574, 69230 Saint-Genis-Laval, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"An atlas of MUSE observations towards twelve massive lensing clusters\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2021/02/12\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2021/02/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"646\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A83\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/202039462\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2021A%26A...646A..83R\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2021/02/aa39462-20.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: distances and redshifts\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"techniques: imaging spectroscopy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Context.&lt;i/&gt; Spectroscopic surveys of massive galaxy clusters reveal the properties of faint background galaxies thanks to the magnification provided by strong gravitational lensing.&lt;i&gt;Aims.&lt;i/&gt; We present a systematic analysis of integral-field-spectroscopy observations of 12 massive clusters, conducted with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE). All data were taken under very good seeing conditions (\u223c0\u2033\u200b\u200b.6) in effective exposure times between two and 15 h per pointing, for a total of 125 h. Our observations cover a total solid angle of \u223c23 arcmin&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;sup/&gt; in the direction of clusters, many of which were previously studied by the MAssive Clusters Survey, Frontier Fields (FFs), Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space and Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with &lt;i&gt;Hubble&lt;i/&gt; programmes. The achieved emission line detection limit at 5&lt;i&gt;\u03c3&lt;i/&gt; for a point source varies between (0.77\u20131.5) \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;\u221218&lt;sup/&gt; erg s&lt;sup&gt;\u22121&lt;sup/&gt; cm&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt; at 7000 \u00c5.&lt;i&gt;Methods.&lt;i/&gt; We present our developed strategy to reduce these observational data, detect continuum sources and line emitters in the datacubes, and determine their redshifts. We constructed robust mass models for each cluster to further confirm our redshift measurements using strong-lensing constraints, and identified a total of 312 strongly lensed sources producing 939 multiple images.&lt;i&gt;Results.&lt;i/&gt; The final redshift catalogues contain more than 3300 robust redshifts, of which 40% are for cluster members and \u223c30% are for lensed Lyman-&lt;i&gt;\u03b1&lt;i/&gt; emitters. Fourteen percent of all sources are line emitters that are not seen in the available HST images, even at the depth of the FFs (\u223c29 AB). We find that the magnification distribution of the lensed sources in the high-magnification regime (&lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;\u2004=\u20042\u201325) follows the theoretical expectation of &lt;i&gt;N&lt;i/&gt;(&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;) \u221d &lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt;. The quality of this dataset, number of lensed sources, and number of strong-lensing constraints enables detailed studies of the physical properties of both the lensing cluster and the background galaxies. The full data products from this work, including the datacubes, catalogues, extracted spectra, ancillary images, and mass models, are made available to the community.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=ERC; citation_grant_number=336736;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=V. {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n figures</a></li>\n</ul></div>\n<div id=\"contenu\">\n<a name=\"top_full\"></a><div id=\"head\">A&amp;A 646, A83 (2021)<h2 class=\"title\">An atlas of MUSE observations towards twelve massive lensing clusters<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#FN1\">&#8902;</a></sup>\n</h2>\n<div class=\"article-authors\"><p class=\"bold\"><span id=\"aa39462-20-author-1\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=1\" class=\"author author-orcid\">Johan Richard</span><sup>1</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-2\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=2\" class=\"author\">Ad&#233;la&#239;de Claeyssens</span><sup>1</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-3\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=3\" class=\"author\">David Lagattuta</span><sup>1</sup><sup>,2</sup><sup>,3</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-4\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=4\" class=\"author\">Lucia Guaita</span><sup>4</sup><sup>,5</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-5\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=5\" class=\"author\">Franz Erik Bauer</span><sup>4</sup><sup>,6</sup><sup>,7</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-6\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=6\" class=\"author\">Roser Pello</span><sup>8</sup><sup>,9</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-7\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=7\" class=\"author\">David Carton</span><sup>1</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-8\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=8\" class=\"author\">Roland Bacon</span><sup>1</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-9\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=9\" class=\"author\">Genevi&#232;ve Soucail</span><sup>8</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-10\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=10\" class=\"author\">Gonzalo Prieto Lyon</span><sup>4</sup><sup>,6</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-11\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=11\" class=\"author\">Jean-Paul Kneib</span><sup>10</sup><sup>,9</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-12\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=12\" class=\"author\">Guillaume Mahler</span><sup>1</sup><sup>,11</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-13\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=13\" class=\"author\">Benjamin Cl&#233;ment</span><sup>1</sup><sup>,10</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-14\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=14\" class=\"author\">Wilfried Mercier</span><sup>8</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-15\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=15\" class=\"author\">Andrei Variu</span><sup>10</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-16\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=16\" class=\"author\">Am&#233;lie Tamone</span><sup>10</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-17\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=17\" class=\"author\">Harald Ebeling</span><sup>12</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-18\" Schmidt</span><sup>13</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-19\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=19\" class=\"author\">Themiya Nanayakkara</span><sup>14</sup><sup>,15</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-20\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=20\" class=\"author\">Michael Maseda</span><sup>14</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-21\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=21\" class=\"author\">Peter M. Weilbacher</span><sup>13</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-22\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=22\" class=\"author\">Nicolas Bouch&#233;</span><sup>1</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-23\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=23\" class=\"author\">Rychard J. Bouwens</span><sup>14</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-24\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=24\" class=\"author\">Lutz Wisotzki</span><sup>13</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-25\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=25\" class=\"author\">Geoffroy de la Vieuville</span><sup>8</sup>, <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-26\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=26\" class=\"author\">Johany Martinez</span><sup>1</sup> and <span id=\"aa39462-20-author-27\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/202039462&amp;n=27\" class=\"author\">Vera Patr&#237;cio</span><sup>1</sup></p></div>\n<p class=\"aff\">\n<sup>1</sup> \n \nUniv Lyon, Univ Lyon1, ENS de Lyon, CNRS, Centre de Recherche Astrophysique de Lyon UMR5574,  69230   Saint-Genis-Laval,  France \n \n\n<br>e-mail: johan.richard@univ-lyon1.fr<br>\n<sup>2</sup> \n \nCentre for Extragalactic Astronomy, Durham University,  South Road,  Durham   DH1 3LE,  UK \n \n<br>\n<sup>3</sup> \n \nInstitute for Computational Cosmology, Durham University,  South Road,  Durham   DH1 3LE,  UK \n \n<br>\n<sup>4</sup> \n \nInstituto de Astrof&#237;sica and Centro de Astroingenier&#237;a, Facultad de F&#237;sica, Pontificia Universidad Cat&#243;lica de Chile,  Casilla 306,  Santiago 22,  Chile \n \n<br>\n<sup>5</sup> \n \nN&#250;cleo de Astronom&#237;a, Facultad de Ingenier&#237;a, Universidad Diego Portales, Av. Ej&#233;rcito 441,  Santiago,  Chile \n \n<br>\n<sup>6</sup> \n \n Millennium Institute of Astrophysics (MAS),  Nuncio Monse&#241;or S&#243;tero Sanz 100,  Providencia,  Santiago,  Chile \n \n<br>\n<sup>7</sup> \n \n Space Science Institute, 4750 Walnut Street, Suite 205,  Boulder,  CO   80301,  USA \n \n<br>\n<sup>8</sup> \n \nInstitut de Recherche en Astrophysique et Plan&#233;tologie (IRAP), Universit&#233; de Toulouse, CNRS, UPS, CNES, 14 Av. Edouard Belin,  31400   Toulouse,  France \n \n<br>\n<sup>9</sup> \n \nAix Marseille Universit&#233;, CNRS, CNES, LAM (Laboratoire d&#8217;Astrophysique de Marseille), UMR 7326,  13388   Marseille,  France \n \n<br>\n<sup>10</sup> \n \nInstitute of Physics, Laboratory of Astrophysics, Ecole Polytechnique F&#233;d&#233;rale de Lausanne (EPFL), Observatoire de Sauverny,  1290   Versoix,  Switzerland \n \n<br>\n<sup>11</sup> \n \nDepartment of Astronomy, University of Michigan,  1085 South University Ave,  Ann Arbor,  MI   48109,  USA \n \n<br>\n<sup>12</sup> \n \nInstitute for Astronomy, University of Hawaii,  2680 Woodlawn Dr,  Honolulu,  HI   96822,  USA \n \n<br>\n<sup>13</sup> \n \n Leibniz-Institut f&#252;r Astrophysik Potsdam (AIP),  An der Sternwarte 16,  14482   Potsdam,  Germany \n \n<br>\n<sup>14</sup> \n \nLeiden Observatory, Leiden University,  PO Box 9513,  2300 RA   Leiden,  The Netherlands \n \n<br>\n<sup>15</sup> \n \nCentre for Astrophysics and Supercomputing, Swinburne University of Technology,  Hawthorn,  VIC   3122,  Australia \n \n<br></p>\n<p class=\"history\"><span class=\"bold\">Received: </span>\n17 \nSeptember \n2020\n<br><span class=\"bold\">Accepted: </span>\n8 \nDecember \n2020\n</p>\n<p class=\"bold\"><a name=\"abs\"></a>Abstract</p>\n<p><i>Context.</i> Spectroscopic surveys of massive galaxy clusters reveal the properties of faint background galaxies thanks to the magnification provided by strong gravitational lensing.</p>\n<p><i>Aims.</i> We present a systematic analysis of integral-field-spectroscopy observations of 12 massive clusters, conducted with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE). All data were taken under very good seeing conditions (&#8764;0&#8243;&#8203;&#8203;.6) in effective exposure times between two and 15 h per pointing, for a total of 125 h. Our observations cover a total solid angle of &#8764;23 arcmin<sup>2</sup> in the direction of clusters, many of which were previously studied by the MAssive Clusters Survey, Frontier Fields (FFs), Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space and Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with <i>Hubble</i> programmes. The achieved emission line detection limit at 5<i>&#963;</i> for a point source varies between (0.77&#8211;1.5) &#215; 10<sup>&#8722;18</sup> erg s<sup>&#8722;1</sup> cm<sup>&#8722;2</sup> at 7000 &#197;.</p>\n<p><i>Methods.</i> We present our developed strategy to reduce these observational data, detect continuum sources and line emitters in the datacubes, and determine their redshifts. We constructed robust mass models for each cluster to further confirm our redshift measurements using strong-lensing constraints, and identified a total of 312 strongly lensed sources producing 939 multiple images.</p>\n<p><i>Results.</i> The final redshift catalogues contain more than 3300 robust redshifts, of which 40% are for cluster members and &#8764;30% are for lensed Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters. Fourteen percent of all sources are line emitters that are not seen in the available HST images, even at the depth of the FFs (&#8764;29 AB). We find that the magnification distribution of the lensed sources in the high-magnification regime (<i>&#956;</i>&#8196;=&#8196;2&#8211;25) follows the theoretical expectation of <i>N</i>(<i>z</i>) &#8733; <i>&#956;</i><sup>&#8722;2</sup>. The quality of this dataset, number of lensed sources, and number of strong-lensing constraints enables detailed studies of the physical properties of both the lensing cluster and the background galaxies. The full data products from this work, including the datacubes, catalogues, extracted spectra, ancillary images, and mass models, are made available to the community.</p>\n<div class=\"kword\"><p><span class=\"bold\">Key words: </span>galaxies: distances and redshifts / galaxies: high-redshift / techniques: imaging spectroscopy / gravitational lensing: strong / galaxies: formation / galaxies: clusters: general</p></div>\n<div class=\"note\">\n<hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div>\n<a name=\"FN1\"></a><sup>&#8902;</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">The dataset and full Tables A.1. and A.2 are only available at the CDS via anonymous ftp to <tt><a href=\"http://cdsarc.u-strasbg.fr/\" target=\"_blank\">cdsarc.u-strasbg.fr</a></tt> (<tt><a href=\"ftp://130.79.128.5\" target=\"_blank\">130.79.128.5</a></tt>) or via <a href=\"http://cdsarc.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/cat/J/A+A/646/A83\" target=\"_blank\">http://cdsarc.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/cat/J/A+A/646/A83</a></p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p><i>&#169; J. Richard et al. 2021</i></p>\n<div class=\"license\">\n<p><a rel=\"license\" href=\"http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0\"><img alt=\"Licence Creative Commons\" src=\"https://i.creativecommons.org/l/by/4.0/88x31.png\"></a>Open Access article, <a href=\"http://www.edpsciences.org\" target=\"_blank\">published by EDP Sciences</a>, under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License (<a href=\"http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0\" target=\"_blank\">http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0</a>), which permits unrestricted use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited.</p>\n</div>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S1\"></a>1. Introduction</h2>\n<p>Strong gravitational lensing by massive galaxy clusters leads to the magnification of sources lying behind them, and this amplification can reach very large factors in the cluster cores (<i>&#956;</i>&#8198;&#8196;&#8764;&#8196;&#8198;5&#8211;10, <a name=\"InR66\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R66\">Kneib &amp; Natarajan 2011</a>), and even higher factors for images in the vicinity of the so-called critical lines (<a name=\"InR102\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R102\">Seitz et al. 1998</a>). For this reason, massive clusters are sometimes referred to as nature&#8217;s telescopes since the combined power of large diameter telescopes and gravitational magnifications provide us with the best views of background galaxies in the distant Universe. Since the first spectroscopic confirmation of a giant gravitational arc was reported (<a name=\"InR105\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R105\">Soucail et al. 1988</a>), high resolution images from the <i>Hubble</i> Space Telescope (HST) have significantly contributed to the success of lensing clusters, with the discovery of a high density of multiple images in deep observations (e.g., <a name=\"InR64\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R64\">Kneib et al. 1996</a>; <a name=\"InR19\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R19\">Broadhurst et al. 2005</a>; <a name=\"InR57\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R57\">Jauzac et al. 2015</a>). Indeed, multiply-imaged systems give us the most precise constraints on the mass distribution in the cluster cores, and consequently the magnification factors.</p>\n<p>Multi-object spectrographs on 8&#8211;10 m class telescopes have helped start large spectroscopic campaigns to confirm the lensed nature of very distant galaxies and the identification of multiple images (e.g., <a name=\"InR25\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R25\">Campusano et al. 2001</a>; <a name=\"InR11\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R11\">Bayliss et al. 2011</a>). However these large spectroscopic campaigns were largely limited by the crowding of galaxy clusters in their central regions, which leads to strong contamination between cluster galaxies and background sources as well as an inefficient use of multi-object spectrographs. In addition, the redshift distribution of lensed sources peaks at <i>z</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;1.5 in the redshift desert, where only the brightest UV-selected galaxies can be confirmed in the optical (<a name=\"InR75\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R75\">Limousin et al. 2007</a>). Because of these limitations, typically only a small number of multiply-imaged systems (typically &lt; 10) have been spectroscopically confirmed in a given cluster with such instruments (e.g., <a name=\"InR96\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R96\">Richard et al. 2010</a>). Several observing campaigns have focused on near-infrared spectroscopy to avoid the redshift desert and complement optical observations (e.g., HST grism <a name=\"InR108\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R108\">Treu et al. 2015</a>, or Keck/MOSFIRE <a name=\"InR51\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R51\">Hoag et al. 2015</a>).</p>\n<p>The advent of the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE, <a name=\"InR6\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R6\">Bacon et al. 2010</a>) on the Very Large Telescope (VLT) has revolutionised the study of strong lensing galaxy clusters. MUSE is a panoramic integral field spectrograph, fully covering a 1 arcmin<sup>2</sup> field of view with spectroscopy in the optical range (475&#8211;930 nm). Together with its very high throughput (40% end-to-end including thetelescope and atmosphere), medium resolution (<i>R</i>&#8196;&#8764;&#8196;3000), and fine spatial sampling (0<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq1.gif\"></span>2), MUSE is very well-suited for crowded field spectroscopy (<a name=\"InR100\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R100\">Roth et al. 2018</a>), and more specifically in galaxy cluster cores. Its pairing with the ground-layer Adaptive Optics (AO) system in 2017 (<a name=\"InR74\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R74\">Leibundgut et al. 2017</a>) has improved its observing efficiency even further.</p>\n<p>The versatile capabilities of MUSE on galaxy cluster fields were demonstrated almost immediately: in commissionning (<a name=\"InR98\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R98\">Richard et al. 2015</a>), science verification (<a name=\"InR63\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R63\">Karman et al. 2015</a>) and regular observations (e.g., <a name=\"InR58\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R58\">Jauzac et al. 2016</a>; <a name=\"InR45\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R45\">Grillo et al. 2016</a>; <a name=\"InR22\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R22\">Caminha et al. 2017a</a>; <a name=\"InR68\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R68\">Lagattuta et al. 2017</a>, <a name=\"InR69\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R69\">2019</a>; <a name=\"InR78\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R78\">Mahler et al. 2018</a>). Most notably, it has been very successful to follow up on the Frontier Field clusters (hereafter FFs; <a name=\"InR77\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R77\">Lotz et al. 2017</a>), a programme initiated by STScI to get deep observations of six massive clusters with the <i>Hubble</i> (HST) and <i>Spitzer</i> space telescopes. But MUSE was also very successful to follow up on clusters with shallower HST images (e.g., <a name=\"InR59\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R59\">Jauzac et al. 2019</a>; <a name=\"InR79\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R79\">Mahler et al. 2019</a>; <a name=\"InR93\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R93\">Rescigno et al. 2020</a>).</p>\n<p>This success has pushed several teams to analyse MUSE observations of known massive clusters such as the Cluster Lensing and Supernova Survey with <i>Hubble</i> (CLASH, <a name=\"InR90\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R90\">Postman et al. 2012</a>) programme (<a name=\"InR94\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R94\">Rexroth et al. 2017</a>; <a name=\"InR24\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R24\">Caminha et al. 2019</a>; <a name=\"InR60\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R60\">Jauzac et al. 2020</a>). Indeed, the richness of the MUSE spectroscopic datasets have a strong legacy aspect, for example to identify small-scale gravitational lenses in the clusters (<a name=\"InR81\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R81\">Meneghetti et al. 2020</a>), or cross-match with multiwavelength observations of the same fields (e.g., with ALMA; <a name=\"InR70\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R70\">Laporte et al. 2017</a>; <a name=\"InR42\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R42\">Fujimoto et al. 2020</a>).</p>\n<p>In this paper, we present a full analysis of 12 lensing clusters, totalling more than 125 hours of exposure time with the MUSE instrument. These observations are in majority taken as part of the MUSE Guaranteed Time Observations (GTO) programme, but are complemented by additional MUSE datasets publicly available on the same clusters or following a similar target selection. We have benefited from many years of developments in MUSE analysis tools as part of the MUSE GTO programmes (<a name=\"InR8\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R8\">Bacon et al. 2017</a>; <a name=\"InR55\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R55\">Inami et al. 2017</a>; <a name=\"InR89\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R89\">Piqueras et al. 2019</a>) to improve the data reduction, source detection and analysis. The results of this analysis are made available in the form of a public data release.</p>\n<p>This paper is organised as follows. Section <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S2\">2</a> presents the target selection, observations and data reduction for the MUSE and ancillary datasets used in our analysis. Section <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S9\">3</a> describes the construction of the spectroscopic catalogues contained in the data release and Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S25\">4</a> describes the mass models we use to estimate the magnification and source properties. We provide an overview of the full spectroscopic catalogue and a few science highlights in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S28\">5</a>, and give our conclusions in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S33\">6</a>.</p>\n<p>Throughout the paper, we assume a standard &#923;-cold dark matter (CDM) cosmological model with &#937;<sub><i>M</i></sub>&#8196;=&#8196;0.3, &#937;<sub>&#923;</sub>&#8196;=&#8196;0.7, and <i>H</i><sub>0</sub>&#8196;=&#8196;70 km s<sup>&#8722;1</sup> Mpc<sup>&#8722;1</sup> whenever necessary. At the typical redshift of the lensing clusters (<i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;0.4), 1&#8243; covers a physical distance of 5.373 kpc. All magnitudes are given in the AB system.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S2\"></a>2. Observations and data reduction</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S3\"></a>2.1. Cluster sample</h3>\n<p>The observations used in our analysis focus on the cores of massive galaxy clusters from both the MUSE Lensing Cluster GTO programme and available archival programmes that target similar clusters. Cluster fields in the MUSE GTO programme were chosen based on their strong-lensing efficiency at magnifying background sources, in particular Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> Emitters (LAEs) at <i>z</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;3 expected to be detected within the MUSE spectral range.</p>\n<p>We compile our sample from a master list of massive X-ray luminous clusters, mainly from the ROSAT Brightest Cluster Sample (BCS, <a name=\"InR34\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R34\">Ebeling et al. 1998</a>, <a name=\"InR35\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R35\">2000</a>) and the MAssive Cluster Survey (MACS, <a name=\"InR36\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R36\">Ebeling et al. 2001</a>), along with its southern counterpart, SMACS. Valuable follow-up imaging with the HST was performed in particular for MACS and SMACS clusters for HST SNAPshot programmes GO-10491, -10875, -11103, -12166, and -12884 (PI Ebeling), allowing the identification of strong-lensing features in the form of arcs and arclets in almost every single target (e.g., <a name=\"InR37\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R37\">Ebeling et al. 2007</a>; <a name=\"InR92\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R92\">Repp et al. 2016</a>).</p>\n<p>To build the sample, we chose targets based on the following selection criteria: firstly a cluster redshift 0.2&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>z</i><sub>cl</sub>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;0.6, to ensure that the main spectral signatures (K,H absorption lines and 4000 break) of cluster members are located in a low-background region of the MUSE spectrum; secondly, a wide range in Right Ascension (RA), to allow easier scheduling with respect to the rest of MUSE GTO observations, and a transit at low airmass (&lt;1.25) as seen from Cerro Paranal Observatory, corresponding to declinations &#8722;60&#8196;&lt; &#8196;Dec&#8196;&lt; &#8196;+10 degrees. Thirdly, we require at least one existing high-resolution broad-band HST image (in either the <i>F</i>606<i>W</i> or <i>F</i>814<i>W</i> filter to ensure overlap with the MUSE spectral range), that shows bright arcs and multiple images; these images are critical to pinpoint the location of sources sufficiently bright in the continuum. Finally, we require a preliminary mass model based on HST images and spectroscopic confirmation of at least one multiply imaged system to roughly estimate the total mass in the cluster core. From this crude map the MUSE observations could be designed to efficiently cover the critical lines and multiple-image region.</p>\n<p>For clusters observed in the framework of the MUSE GTO, the choice of the precise centre for the pointing, or the mosaic configuration, were determined in such a way that the observed area included as far as possible the tangential critical lines, in order to maximise the number of strongly magnified and multiple images (see also Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S15\">3.6</a>).</p>\n<p>We present here the results for a set of 12 clusters selected through this process, all of which were analysed in a uniform manner. The combination of the aforementioned criteria makes our selection similar to the one used in other cluster surveys such as CLASH and the FFs. It is therefore not surprising that half of the clusters we selected overlap with these two programmes.</p>\n<p>The main properties of the 12 selected clusters are summarised in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T1\">1</a>. Additional clusters observed as part of the GTO programme will be analysed following the same procedure as described in this paper, and included in a future data release.</p>\n<p><a name=\"T1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1.</span></a>\n<p>Summary of selected lensing clusters.</p>\n</div></div></p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S4\"></a>2.2. MUSE GTO survey</h3>\n<p>The MUSE Lensing Cluster project (PI: Richard) is a multi-semester programme, which has been running since ESO semester P94 starting in Fall 2014. It targets the central regions of the massive lensing clusters introduced in the previous section, with an effective exposure time of 2&#8722;10 h per pointing. Data are acquired in Wide Field Mode (WFM), using both standard (WFM-NOAO-N) and adaptive-optics (WFM-AO-N) observations &#8211; the latter configuration having been available since Fall 2017, following the commissioning of the ground layer Adaptive Optics (AO) correction. Although the AO mode improves the seeing, we note that WFM-AO-N datasets have a gap in the 5800&#8211;5980 &#197; wavelength range due to the AO notch filter. Additionally, while nearly all of the data are acquired in Nominal mode, covering the 4750&#8211;9350 &#197; wavelength range, one exception is the Bullet cluster, for which observations were taken in Extended mode (WFM-NOAO-E) covering bluer wavelengths (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S7\">2.5</a>).</p>\n<p>The location and orientation of each MUSE pointing has been chosen to maximise the coverage of the multiply-imaged regions (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F1\">1</a>), and also to guarantee the availability of suitable Tip-Tilt stars for observations taken in WFM-AO-N mode. In the case of FF and CLASH clusters, we adopted a coverage of larger mosaics of multiple contiguous MUSE pointings to increase the legacy value of these datasets, in coordination with non-GTO programmes (see below).</p>\n<p><a name=\"F1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1.</span></a>\n<p>MUSE exposure maps overlayed on top of the HST/<i>F</i>814<i>W</i> images. The 12 clusters from Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T1\">1</a> are displayed in reading order, with the reference position from the same table marked as a white cross.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div></p>\n<p>The observations were split into blocks of &#8764;1&#8211;1.15 h execution time. Each observing block consists in either 2 &#215; 1800 s, 3 &#215; 900 s or 3 &#215; 1000 s. exposures. We included a small spatial dithering box (&lt;0<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq2.gif\"></span>3) as well as 90 degrees rotations of the instrument between each exposure. Indeed this strategy has been shown to help reduce the systematics due to the IFU image slicer (<a name=\"InR7\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R7\">Bacon et al. 2015</a>). A summary of all exposures taken is provided in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T2\">2</a>.</p>\n<p><a name=\"T2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/T2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 2.</span></a>\n<p>Summary of MUSE observations analysed on the 12 clusters.</p>\n</div></div></p>\n<p>Standard calibrations have been used for this programme, including day-time instrument calibrations as well as standard star observations. All exposures taken after the 2nd MUSE commissioning in June 2014 (i.e. all cluster fields presented here except for SMACS2031) include single internal flat-field exposures taken with the instrument as night calibrations. These short (0.35 s) exposures are used for an illumination correction and taken every hour, or whenever there is a sudden temperature change in the instrument. These calibrations are important to correct for time and temperature dependence on the flat-field calibration between each slitlet throughout the night. In addition, twilight exposures are taken every few days and are used to produce an on-sky illumination correction between the 24 channels.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S5\"></a>2.3. MUSE archival data</h3>\n<p>The importance of getting deep MUSE exposures on the FFs has led us to coordinate a joint effort between the GTO programme and additional programmes towards MACS0416 and Abell 370 (ESO programmes 094.A-0525 and 096.A-0710 respectively, PI: Bauer). Overall, the same strategy as for the GTO campaign has been followed for these observations, and were combined with GTO data when overlapping. Similarly, additional exposure time in the northern part of the FF cluster MACS0416 has been obtained as part of ESO programme 0100.A-0764 (PI: Vanzella, <a name=\"InR113\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R113\">Vanzella et al. 2021</a>), and combined with the GTO observations.</p>\n<p>Finally, we include in our analysis two CLASH clusters observed as part of ESO programmes 095.A-0525, 096.A-0105, 097.A-0909 (PI: Kneib) on MACS0329 and RXJ1347, again with very similar science goals and observing strategy to the GTO programme. A first analysis on these datasets with only partial exposure time was presented in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R24\">Caminha et al. (2019)</a> and we present here a more detailed analysis of the full datasets after homogeneous reduction as for the other fields.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S6\"></a>2.4. Ancillary HST data</h3>\n<p>We make use of the available high-resolution WFPC2, ACS/WFC, and WFC3-IR images in the optical/near-infrared covering the MUSE observations. Six clusters in our sample are included in the CLASH (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R90\">Postman et al. 2012</a>) and FF (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R77\">Lotz et al. 2017</a>) surveys, for which High Level Science Products (HLSP) incorporating all observations taken in 12 and 6 filters respectively have been aligned and combined. We use the HLSP images provided by the Space Telescope at the respective repositories for CLASH<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#FN3\">1</a></sup> and FFs<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#FN4\">2</a></sup>.</p>\n<p>For the remaining six clusters, Snapshot and GO programmes on HST were obtained as part of the MACS survey (PI: Ebeling) as well as follow-up HST programmes (PIs: Bradac, Egami). The details of the HST programmes and available bands are given in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T3\">3</a>, and were used in previous strong-lensing work. We make use of the reduced HST images available in the <i>Hubble</i> Legacy Archive (HLA).</p>\n<p><a name=\"T3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/T3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 3.</span></a>\n<p>Details of the HST programs and filters used for the 6 clusters which are not part of the FF or CLASH samples.</p>\n</div></div></p>\n<p>Following the MUSE observations on MACS0940, we have obtained as part of HST programme 15696 (PI: Carton) new images with ACS and WFC3-IR at a higher resolution and going much deeper than the previous WFPC2 snapshot in <i>F</i>606<i>W</i>. Three orbits were obtained in <i>F</i>814<i>W</i> (totalling 7526 s), one orbit in <i>F</i>125<i>W</i> (totalling 2605 s) and 1.5 orbits in <i>F</i>160<i>W</i> (totalling 3900 s). We have aligned and drizzled the individual calibrated exposures for each band using the <tt>astroDrizzle</tt> and <tt>TweakReg</tt> utilities (<a name=\"InR67\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R67\">Koekemoer et al. 2011</a>).</p>\n<p>All HLSP datasets were already calibrated for absolute astrometry. The HST images for the remaining 6 clusters were aligned against one another and with respect to star positions in J2000 selected from the <i>Gaia</i> Data Release 2 (<a name=\"InR43\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R43\">Gaia Collaboration 2018</a>) catalogue. The accuracy of the absolute astrometry is &lt; 0<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq3.gif\"></span>06.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S7\"></a>2.5. MUSE data reduction</h3>\n<p>For consistency, data from each cluster are reduced using a common pipeline, which processes the raw exposures retrieved from the ESO archive into a fully-calibrated combined datacube. This sequence largely follows the main standard steps described in <a name=\"InR115\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R115\">Weilbacher et al. (2020)</a> as well as the MUSE Data Reduction Pipeline User Manual<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#FN5\">3</a></sup>. However, we make some modifications due to the crowded nature of lensing cluster fields, which contain extended bright objects. We summarise each step below. While the specific version of the Data Reduction Pipeline used on each cluster ranged between v2.4 to v2.7, there are only minor changes between these versions, and these do not affect the quality of the resulting datacubes.</p>\n<p>The first step in the pipeline provides basic calibrations. Raw calibration exposures are combined and analysed to produce a master bias, master flat and trace table (which locates the edges of the slitlets on the detectors), as well as the wavelength solution and Line Spread Function (LSF) estimate for each observing night. These calibrations are then applied on all the raw science exposures to produce a pixel table propagating the information on each detector pixel without any interpolation. A bad pixel map is used to reject known detector defects, and we make use of the geometry table created once for each observing run to precisely locate the slitlets from the 24 detectors over the MUSE FoV. Twilight exposures and night-time internal flat calibrations (when available) are used for additional illumination correction.</p>\n<p>The second step of the data reduction makes use of the <tt>muse_scipost</tt> module of the data reduction pipeline to process science pixel tables. The calibrations performed in this step include flux calibration using standard star exposures taken at the beginning of the night, telluric correction, auto-calibration (detailed below), sky subtraction, differential atmospheric refraction correction, relative astrometry and radial velocity correction to barycentric velocity. In the case of WFM-AO-N observations with adaptive optics, laser-induced Raman lines are also fit and subtracted.</p>\n<p>Each calibrated pixel table is then resampled onto a datacube with associated variance, regularly sampled at a spatial pixel (hereafter spaxel) scale of 0<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq4.gif\"></span>2 and a wavelength step of 1.25 &#197;, between 4750 (4600 for WFM-NOAO-E) and 9350 &#197;. The drizzling method from <tt>muse_scipost</tt> is used in the resampling process, which also performs a rejection of cosmic-rays. A white light image is constructed for each datacube by inverse-variance weighted averaging all pixel values along the spectral axis. Individual white light images are used to measure spatial offsets between individual exposures. This is done either through the use of the <tt>muse_exp _align</tt> task of the data reduction pipeline, or by locating point sources against an HST image in the <i>F</i>606<i>W</i> or <i>F</i>814<i>W</i> filter, in the case of large MUSE mosaics. The measured offsets are then used to produce fully aligned (in World Coordinate System, or WCS) datacubes for each exposure.</p>\n<p>Once resampled to the same WCS pixel grid, all datacubes are finally combined together outside of the pipeline using the MPDAF<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#FN6\">4</a></sup> (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R89\">Piqueras et al. 2019</a>) software task <tt>CubeList.combine</tt>, or its equivalent <tt>CubeMosaic.pycombine</tt> for large mosaics. This allows one to perform an inverse-variance weighted average over a large number of datacubes. A 3&#8211;5<i>&#963;</i> rejection (depending on the number of exposures) of the input pixels was applied in the average, to remove remaining defects and cosmic rays, totalling &#8764;5&#8211;10% of all pixels in each exposure. We visually inspected each individual white light image and manually rejected very few obvious cases of light contamination, issues in telescope tracking, etc. from the combination. We also masked 4 cases of satellite and asteroid trails by selecting and masking the relevant spaxels across the cubes. We estimated variations in atmospheric transmission by comparing the total flux of bright isolated sources between individual exposures and provided the correction factors as input to <tt>CubeList.combine</tt> or <tt>CubeMosaic.pycombine</tt>.</p>\n<p>Low level systematics due to flat-field residuals (at the &#8764;1% level) remain between each slitlet after applying the internal flat-field calibrations and nightime illuminations. They appear prominently as a weaving pattern over the FoV in the white light image (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F2\">2</a>, left panel). In v2.4 (and subsequent versions) of the data reduction pipeline, an optional self-calibration can be performed as part of <tt>muse_scipost</tt>, which makes use of the overall sky signal within each slitlet to correct for these flat-field systematics. This procedure has been shown to work accurately in MUSE deep fields where very bright continuum sources are scarce (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R8\">Bacon et al. 2017</a>). However the very bright extended cluster light haloes in the MUSE lensing fields, in particular in the vicinity of the Brightest Cluster Galaxies (BCGs) strongly bias this measurement when the procedure is applied automatically (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F2\">2</a>), due to the extent of the Intra-Cluster light (ICL). We have the possibility to give as input to the pipeline a sky mask for the self-calibration procedure, to help the algorithm identify spaxels with a clean background. We constructed this mask in two steps, by thresholding a deep HST continuum image (smoothed by a &#8764;0<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq5.gif\"></span>6 FWHM Gaussian filter) or a MUSE white-light image created from a first combined datacube, and then applying it to produce the self-calibrated exposures. The threshold was determined by inspecting the mask to avoid using a too small fraction of the spaxels in a given slitlet for the background level estimation. In a few very crowded regions we make use of the multiple rotations in the observations to compute the self-calibration corrections only in the most favourable cases, and provide them as a user table (see more details in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R115\">Weilbacher et al. 2020</a>). When deemed necessary, another iteration on the sky mask was performed on the new combined cube to improve the self-calibration further. An illustration of the resulting combined white light image and sky mask is presented in the middle panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F2\">2</a>. In the case of the SMACS J2031 cluster field, which is the only cluster lacking for night-time illumination corrections during the commissioning run, the improvements due to self-calibration are even more significant (see <a name=\"InR28\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R28\">Claeyssens et al. 2019</a>).</p>\n<p><a name=\"F2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2.</span></a>\n<p>Effect of auto-calibration on the white light image (example shown for MACS0940). <i>From left to right</i>: without auto-calibration, using auto-calibration with tuned object masks, with additional interstack masks. See Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S7\">2.5</a> for more details.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div></p>\n<p>The white-light image of the self-calibrated combined datacube shows some imperfections in the sky background, in the form of negative &#8216;holes&#8217; in the interstacks between the MUSE slices, in particular within the top channels of the instrument. These can typically be corrected in empty fields by producing a super-flat calibration (Bacon et al., in prep.) combining all exposures in the instrument frame of reference while masking objects. However this method is not suited for crowded cluster fields. Instead, we aligned all the individual white light exposures in the instrument referential frame by inverting all WCS offsets and rotations between exposures, then detected deviant spaxels with strongly negative flux over the average combined image. This produces a small mask containing &#8764;0.6% of the FoV, which we use to mask pixels in the datacubes at all wavelengths prior to combination. This results in the removal of the majority of the imperfections as seen in the white-light image (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F2\">2</a>, right panel).</p>\n<p>The combined datacube is finally processed using the Zurich Atmospheric Purge (ZAP, <a name=\"InR104\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R104\">Soto et al. 2016</a>) v2, which performs a subtraction of remaining sky residuals based on a Principal Component Analysis (PCA) of the spectra in the background regions of the datacube. This has been shown to remove most of the systematics in particular towards the longer wavelengths (see e.g., <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R8\">Bacon et al. 2017</a> in the UDF). We provide as input to ZAP an object mask by inverting the sky mask described above. Although the number of eigenvectors removed is automatically selected by ZAP, we have performed multiple tests adjusting this number to check that the chosen value did not affect the extracted spectra of faint continuum and line emitting sources.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S8\"></a>2.6. MUSE data quality</h3>\n<p>The reduced datacube is given as a FITS file with two extensions, containing the <i>f</i><sub><i>&#955;</i></sub> and associated variance over a regular 3D grid. The spectral resolution of the observations varies from <i>R</i>&#8196;=&#8196;2000 to <i>R</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4000, with a spectral range between 4750 and 9350 &#197;. To ensure that cubes are properly Nyquist sampled, we set the wavelength grid to 1.25 &#197; pixel<sup>&#8722;1</sup>. The final spatial sampling is 0.2 arcsec pixel<sup>&#8722;1</sup> in order to properly sample the Point Spread Function (PSF).</p>\n<p>We have cross-checked the relative astrometry between the MUSE cubes and the HST images presented in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S6\">2.4</a>, by cross-matching bright sources in the two datasets. We measure a global rms of &#8764;0<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq6.gif\"></span>12, that is to say about half a MUSE spaxel.</p>\n<p>In order to estimate the spatial Point Spread Function, which varies as a function of wavelength, we have followed the MUSE <i>Hubble</i> Ultra Deep Field approach, described by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R8\">Bacon et al. (2017)</a>. From the MUSE datacube we produce pseudo-HST images in the bandpasses matching the HST filters (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T3\">3</a>) and overlapping with the MUSE spectral range. These images are compared with pseudo-MUSE images created from HST and convolved with a <a name=\"InR82\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R82\">Moffat (1969)</a> PSF at fixed <i>&#946;</i>&#8196;=&#8196;2.5. The FWHM of the Moffat function is optimised by minimising the residuals in Fourier space. This method allows to use all objects in the field to measure the PSF.</p>\n<p>The wavelength dependence on the PSF is then adjusted by assuming a linear relation:</p>\n<p><a name=\"FD1\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><a name=\"img_eq7\"></a><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq7.gif\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(1)</span></span></p>\n<p>The slope <i>C</i> of this relation depends on the use of Adaptive Optics, we find values ranging between &#8722;1.9&#8197;&#215;&#8197;10<sup>&#8722;5</sup> and &#8722;3.6&#8197;&#215;&#8197;10<sup>&#8722;5</sup> arcsec &#197;<sup>&#8722;1</sup>, which are similar to the ones from the MUSE Ultra Deep Fields (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R8\">Bacon et al. 2017</a>) and MUSE-Wide (<a name=\"InR109\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R109\">Urrutia et al. 2019</a>). We report for each dataset the FWHM of the PSF at 7000 &#197; in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T2\">2</a>. In general the datacubes have been taken in very good seeing conditions, translating into a typical <i>FWHM</i><sub>7000</sub> value between 0<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq8.gif\"></span>55 and 0<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq9.gif\"></span>65. The only exception is SMACS2031 (<i>FWHM</i><sub>7000</sub> = 0<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq10.gif\"></span>79) which was observed during MUSE commissioning. The same MUSE vs. HST comparison allows us to cross-check the photometric accuracy of the MUSE cubes, and we find an agreement within 5&#8211;10% between the two datasets.</p>\n<p>The variance extension of the cube is estimated during the data reduction and gives an estimate of the noise level which is generally underestimated due to correlation in the noise introduced during the final 3D resampling process (see e.g., <a name=\"InR48\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R48\">Herenz et al. 2017</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R109\">Urrutia et al. 2019</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R115\">Weilbacher et al. 2020</a>). To properly assess the noise properties of each cube as a function of wavelength, we make use of objects-free regions (as defined with the sky masks mentioned in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S7\">2.5</a>) and measure the variance of the flux level integrated over 1&#8243; square apertures. When compared with the direct estimate from the variance extension, the two measurements show a simple constant correction factor between 1.3 and 1.5 on the standard deviation as a function of wavelength (e.g., Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F3\">3</a>). We apply this constant correction factor to the noise estimation of the datacube.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3.</span></a>\n<p>5<i>&#963;</i> continuum flux limit estimated in empty sky region of the MACS0940 datacube (8 h exposure time), including (orange curve) or not (blue curve) the correction for correlated noise. The increased noise level within the AO filter (around 5890 Angstroms) is due to the shorter effective exposure time in WFM-NOAO-N instrument mode (50 min).</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div></p>\n<p>The relative noise levels presented in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F3\">3</a> are very similar in all datacubes (with the exception of the AO filter region which depends on the relative fraction of AO vs. NOAO exposure time), and roughly scale with the square root of the effective exposure time. The 5<i>&#963;</i> surface brightness limits (averaged in a 1 arcsec<sup>2</sup> region) between skylines at 7000 &#197; is 4.8 &#215; 10<sup>&#8722;19</sup> and 2.5 &#215; 10<sup>&#8722;19</sup> erg s<sup>&#8722;1</sup> cm<sup>&#8722;2</sup> &#197;<sup>&#8722;1</sup> arcsec<sup>&#8722;2</sup> for cubes with 2 h and 8 h exposure time respectively. This translates into a 5<i>&#963;</i> line flux limit of 1.5 &#215; 10<sup>&#8722;18</sup> and 7.7 &#215; 10<sup>&#8722;19</sup> erg s<sup>&#8722;1</sup> cm<sup>&#8722;2</sup> at 7000 &#197; when averaged over a 5 &#215; 5 spaxels aperture and 3 wavelength planes (6.25 &#197;).</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S9\"></a>3. Construction of MUSE spectroscopic catalogues</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S10\"></a>3.1. Overview</h3>\n<p>The sheer number of volume pixels (voxels) in a 1 arcmin<sup>2</sup> MUSE datacube (&#8764;4&#8197;&#215;&#8197;10<sup>8</sup>) makes it challenging to locate and identify all the extragalactic sources; this is especially true when observing crowded fields like galaxy clusters. Prior knowledge of source locations from HST images provides crucial external information to help distinguish and deblend overlapping sources. Our goal is to extract a spectrum and estimate the redshift for all sources down to a limiting signal-to-noise ratio (described in subsequent subsections), either in the stellar continuum or via emission lines. Additional prior information on the redshift of background sources can be obtained for strongly-lensed multiple images, where well-constrained models allow. We have therefore developed a common process to analyse the MUSE datacubes incorporating all these elements.</p>\n<p>The general concept of this procedure has been described previously in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R78\">Mahler et al. (2018)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R69\">Lagattuta et al. (2019)</a>, but we have further refined and partially automated the methods for the subsequent cluster observations presented here, in order to create more uniform and robust catalogues. We summarise each step of the process in the flowchart shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F4\">4</a>, and provide details on each step in the following subsections.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4.</span></a>\n<p>Flowchart presenting the process of building the MUSE spectrophotometric catalogues, based on the input HST images and MUSE datacube. Section <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S9\">3</a> presents each step of the procedure in detail.</p>\n</td>\n</tr></table></div></p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S11\"></a>3.2. HST prior sources</h3>\n<p>We make use of all the available high-resolution HST imaging in each field (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S6\">2.4</a>) to produce input photometric catalogues of continuum sources that overlap with the MUSE FoV to identify regions for subsequent spectral extraction. Since our goal is to measure the spectra of typically faint compact background sources, usually embedded within the bright extended haloes of cluster members, we first produce a median-subtracted version of each image by subtracting a 1<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq11.gif\"></span>5 &#215; 1<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq12.gif\"></span>5 running median filter box. The WCS-aligned, median-subtracted HST images are cropped to the common MUSE area and further combined into an inverse-variance-weighted detection image, using SW<span class=\"smallcaps\">ARP</span> (<a name=\"InR14\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R14\">Bertin et al. 2002</a>).</p>\n<p>This procedure was used in previous works searching for faint high-redshift dropouts (<a name=\"InR4\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R4\">Atek et al. 2015</a>, <a name=\"InR5\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R5\">2018</a>) in deep <i>Hubble</i> FF images, and significantly improves the detection of background sources while still keeping the central cores of all bright cluster members. The negative impact of the median subtraction is a reduction of the isophotal area for bright extended sources in the segmentation map, which reduces the total flux in their extracted MUSE spectra. However, as these sources all have high signal-to-noise ratio in the MUSE datacube, this has no impact on the spectroscopic redshift measurements, and we adjusted the size of the median-box filter in order to mitigate this effect.</p>\n<p>The detection image is given as input to the SE<span class=\"smallcaps\">XTRACTOR</span> software (<a name=\"InR13\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R13\">Bertin &amp; Arnouts 1996</a>) used in dual mode to measure the photometry over each HST band (aligning each band image with M<span class=\"smallcaps\">ONTAGE</span>)<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#FN7\">5</a></sup>. We make use of the HST weight maps to account for variation of depth over the FoV, and selected typical SE<span class=\"smallcaps\">XTRACTOR</span> parameter values <tt>detect_minarea = 10&#8211;15</tt> pixels and <tt>detect_thresh = 1.2&#8211;1.5</tt>. These values were optimised for each cluster to account for variations in depth and pixel scale of the HST images.</p>\n<p>The photometry performed by SE<span class=\"smallcaps\">XTRACTOR</span> in each band is merged together into a photometric catalogue of HST sources, dubbed prior sources through the rest of the paper. SE<span class=\"smallcaps\">XTRACTOR</span> also produces a segmentation map where each spaxel in the MUSE FoV is flagged with a source ID number.</p>\n<p>During the detection process, SE<span class=\"smallcaps\">XTRACTOR</span> tends to split large clumpy sources such as foreground disk galaxies or very elongated arcs into multiple entries in the catalogue. Such cases are visually identified as part of the source inspection and redshift estimation process (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S14\">3.5</a>), and the corresponding photometry and segmentation map are merged together to produce a single prior source located at the HST light barycenter.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S12\"></a>3.3. Line-emitting sources</h3>\n<p>Independent from the HST continuum sources, we produced a catalogue of line-emitter candidates identified directly from the MUSE datacubes. This was performed by running the <tt>muselet</tt> software, which is part of the MPDAF python package (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R89\">Piqueras et al. 2019</a>). <tt>muselet</tt> first creates a &#8216;pseudo-narrow-band&#8217; MUSE datacube by replacing each wavelength plane of the cube with a continuum-subtracted narrow-band image. To generate the narrow-band emission for a given wavelength, we take a weighted average of five planes of the cube (the original wavelength plane and its four nearest neighbours), using a fixed FWHM Gaussian weight function corresponding to 150 km s<sup>&#8722;1</sup> for a line centred at 7000 &#197;. This weighting scheme improves the signal-to-noise ratio of the narrow-band at the centre of a typical emission line of similar FWHM. The subtracted continuum is estimated by an inverse-variance weighted average of two 25 &#197; wide wavelength windows located directly bluewards and redwards of the narrow-band. We have found that these parameters are generally appropriate for an automatic subtraction of the local continuum.</p>\n<p>The full set of narrow-band images is run through SE<span class=\"smallcaps\">XTRACTOR</span> to detect candidate spectral lines at each wavelength. Because we expect some galaxies to show diffuse extended emission, especially Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters, we tune our SE<span class=\"smallcaps\">XTRACTOR</span> detection parameters (<tt>detect_minarea = 12</tt> pixels; <tt>detect_thresh = 1.2</tt>), and spatial smoothing filter (a 5 &#215; 5 pixel tophat with <i>FWHM</i>&#8196;=&#8196;0<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq13.gif\"></span>8) to better identify these objects. By construction, all bright lines will be detected in adjacent wavelength planes, and therefore they are automatically merged into a master list of individual line candidates. We specifically masked three 4 &#197;-wide wavelength regions in the cube corresponding to bright sky lines at 5577 and 6300 &#197; as well as the strongest Raman line at 6825 &#197;, to prevent artefacts in the detections. Sets of lines spatially coincident (within 1 seeing disk) are then grouped together into <tt>muselet</tt> sources and a segmentation map is produced. A first redshift estimate is also provided by <tt>muselet</tt> based on an automatic match with a list of bright emission lines.</p>\n<p>The MPDAF v2.0 of the <tt>muselet</tt> software was used for a first set of clusters (Abell 2744, Abell 370, MACS1206, MACS0416S). MPDAF v3.1 introduces improvements in the merging and weighting schemes of the <tt>muselet</tt> sources, and was used for the rest of the clusters.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S13\"></a>3.4. Spectral extraction</h3>\n<p>In order to characterise the detected prior and <tt>muselet</tt> sources, we adopt the following procedure to extract 1D spectra, which optimises the signal-to-noise of the detections while being adapted to crowded fields. A weight image is created for each source by taking the flux distribution over the segmentation maps produced as part of the detection process. In the case of prior sources this flux distribution is taken from the combination of all HST filters, and the 2D weight map is convolved by the MUSE PSF model described in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S8\">2.6</a>. To account for the wavelength variation of the PSF (Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#FD1\">1</a>)), weight images are created for each source at 10 wavelength planes (i.e. at &#8764;500 &#197; intervals) over the MUSE spectral range and interpolated into a 3D weight cube. In the case of <tt>muselet</tt> sources, the segmentation map used is the one of the brightest emission line of the object. Since we do not account for wavelength variations in the intrinsic flux profiles of galaxies (e.g., colour gradients), the weighted extractions, while optimal for the distant compact sources, are not spectrophotometrically accurate for the extended cluster members.
