The 12 clusters from Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T1\">1</a> are displayed in reading order, with the reference position from the same table marked as a white cross.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F1\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2.</span></a>\n<p>Effect of auto-calibration on the white light image (example shown for MACS0940). <i>From left to right</i>: without auto-calibration, using auto-calibration with tuned object masks, with additional interstack masks. See Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S7\">2.5</a> for more details.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F2\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3.</span></a>\n<p>5<i>&#963;</i> continuum flux limit estimated in empty sky region of the MACS0940 datacube (8 h exposure time), including (orange curve) or not (blue curve) the correction for correlated noise. The increased noise level within the AO filter (around 5890 Angstroms) is due to the shorter effective exposure time in WFM-NOAO-N instrument mode (50 min).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F3\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4.</span></a>\n<p>Flowchart presenting the process of building the MUSE spectrophotometric catalogues, based on the input HST images and MUSE datacube. Section <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#S9\">3</a> presents each step of the procedure in detail.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F4\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5.</span></a>\n<p>Example of faint Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emission (large yellow circle) detected near the position of the predicted counterimage from <tt>muselet</tt> source 641 in cluster MACS0329, at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;6.011 (small white circle). The image shows a smoothed narrow-band image at the peak wavelength of the emission. The dotted ellipse denotes the estimated 1-<i>&#963;</i> error region of the predicted location.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F5\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 6.</span></a>\n<p>Examples of P<span class=\"smallcaps\">YPLATEFIT</span> spectral fitting, for two sources in our catalogues. <i>Top row</i> shows the case of the bright <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4.03 galaxy in MACS0940 (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#R28\">Claeyssens et al. 2019</a>) with <i>zconf</i>&#8196;=&#8196;3 and the <i>bottom row</i> a <tt>MUSELET</tt>-selected galaxy at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;0.337 and <i>zconf</i>&#8196;=&#8196;2 in the same cluster field (M364). The <i>left panel</i> gives an overview of the spectrum, while the <i>middle and right panels</i> zoom in on specific spectral line fits. The best-fit spectrum and global continuum fit are plotted in red and blue, respectively.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F6\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7.</span></a>\n<p>Location of MUSE spectroscopic redshifts over HST F606W-F814W-F160W colour composites. members for each of the 12 fields. We overlay a theoretical <i>&#956;</i><sup>&#8722;2</sup> relation to guide the eye. We observe a significant drop in the number of sources at low magnifications (<i>&#956;</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;1.5), due to the limits set by the FoV of the MUSE observations, and at very high magnifications (<i>&#956;</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;25) due to the very small statistics and possibly the resolved nature of Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F13\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig14_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 11.</span></a>\n<p><i>Left panel</i>: source plane coverage of each cluster at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4, as a function of the strong lensing magnification of the most magnified image. The black square shows a 1 arcmin<sup>2</sup> for scale. <i>Right panel</i>: effective volume surveyed at 2.9&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>z</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;6.7 with MUSE for Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitters, as a function of the magnification of the brightest image. Presented are individual volumes behind each cluster and the total over all fields.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F14\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F15.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig15_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F15.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 12.</span></a>\n<p>Example of very extended Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emitter in RXJ1347 (system 25), at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4.086. <i>Left panel</i> shows the HST colour image and the <i>right panel</i> the MUSE NB image around the Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emission. White dashed contours of the NB are overlayed on HST. The red curve shows the critical line at this redshift, which crosses the arc-shaped Lyman-<i>&#945;</i> emission at the location of a point-like source in HST.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F15\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F16.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig16_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F16.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. B.1.</span></a>\n<p>Overview of all multiply-imaged systems used in the strong-lensing model of MACS0257. The cyan dashed line highlights the limits of the MUSE observations. The white line represents the limit of the region where we expect multiples images. The red line delineates the critical line for a source at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F16\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F17.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig17_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F17.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. B.1.</span></a>\n<p>continued. Same figure for MACS0329.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F17\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F18.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig18_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F18.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. B.1.</span></a>\n<p>continued. Same figure for MACS0416.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F18\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F19.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig19_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F19.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. B.1.</span></a>\n<p>Same as Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F16\">B.1</a> for the Bullet Cluster.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F19\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F20.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-fig20_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/F20.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. B.1.</span></a>\n<p>continued. content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2021/02/aa39462-20.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: distances and redshifts\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"techniques: imaging spectroscopy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Context.&lt;i/&gt; Spectroscopic surveys of massive galaxy clusters reveal the properties of faint background galaxies thanks to the magnification provided by strong gravitational lensing.&lt;i&gt;Aims.&lt;i/&gt; We present a systematic analysis of integral-field-spectroscopy observations of 12 massive clusters, conducted with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE). All data were taken under very good seeing conditions (\u223c0\u2033\u200b\u200b.6) in effective exposure times between two and 15 h per pointing, for a total of 125 h. Our observations cover a total solid angle of \u223c23 arcmin&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;sup/&gt; in the direction of clusters, many of which were previously studied by the MAssive Clusters Survey, Frontier Fields (FFs), Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space and Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with &lt;i&gt;Hubble&lt;i/&gt; programmes. The achieved emission line detection limit at 5&lt;i&gt;\u03c3&lt;i/&gt; for a point source varies between (0.77\u20131.5) \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;\u221218&lt;sup/&gt; erg s&lt;sup&gt;\u22121&lt;sup/&gt; cm&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt; at 7000 \u00c5.&lt;i&gt;Methods.&lt;i/&gt; We present our developed strategy to reduce these observational data, detect continuum sources and line emitters in the datacubes, and determine their redshifts. We constructed robust mass models for each cluster to further confirm our redshift measurements using strong-lensing constraints, and identified a total of 312 strongly lensed sources producing 939 multiple images.&lt;i&gt;Results.&lt;i/&gt; The final redshift catalogues contain more than 3300 robust redshifts, of which 40% are for cluster members and \u223c30% are for lensed Lyman-&lt;i&gt;\u03b1&lt;i/&gt; emitters. Fourteen percent of all sources are line emitters that are not seen in the available HST images, even at the depth of the FFs (\u223c29 AB). We find that the magnification distribution of the lensed sources in the high-magnification regime (&lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;\u2004=\u20042\u201325) follows the theoretical expectation of &lt;i&gt;N&lt;i/&gt;(&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;) \u221d &lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt;. The quality of this dataset, number of lensed sources, and number of strong-lensing constraints enables detailed studies of the physical properties of both the lensing cluster and the background galaxies. The full data products from this work, including the datacubes, catalogues, extracted spectra, ancillary images, and mass models, are made available to the community.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=ERC; citation_grant_number=336736;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=V. {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div 900 (AO)</td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n<td align=\"center\"></td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n      </div>\n      <div class=\"history\">\n<p><b>Notes.</b> It is important to note that the two datasets on MACS0416 cluster (N)orth and (S)outh have been treated separately. From left to right: MUSE dataset, ESO Programs, range of observing dates, list of exposure times and instrument modes, final image quality of the combined datacube (FWHM at 700 nm), range of effective exposure time per spaxel, notes on multiple pointings (see also Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#F1\">1</a>).</p>\n<div><a name=\"TFN1\" id=\"TFN1\"></a><sup>(a)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Taken in extended mode (WFM-NOAO-E).</p></div>\n<div><a name=\"TFN2\" id=\"TFN2\"></a><sup>(b)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">1 exposure stopped after 740 s.</p></div>\n<div><a name=\"TFN3\" id=\"TFN3\"></a><sup>(c)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">1 exposure stopped after 1405 s.</p></div>\n<div><a name=\"TFN4\" id=\"TFN4\"></a><sup>(d)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">MUSE commissioning run .</p></div>\n</div>\n    </div>\n  \n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/202039462\" data-edps_ref=\"aa39462-20\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Univ Lyon, Univ Lyon1, ENS de Lyon, CNRS, Centre de Recherche Astrophysique de Lyon UMR5574, 69230 Saint-Genis-Laval, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"An atlas of MUSE observations towards twelve massive lensing clusters\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2021/02/12\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2021/02/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"646\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A83\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/202039462\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2021A%26A...646A..83R\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2021/02/aa39462-20.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: distances and redshifts\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"techniques: imaging spectroscopy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Context.&lt;i/&gt; Spectroscopic surveys of massive galaxy clusters reveal the properties of faint background galaxies thanks to the magnification provided by strong gravitational lensing.&lt;i&gt;Aims.&lt;i/&gt; We present a systematic analysis of integral-field-spectroscopy observations of 12 massive clusters, conducted with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE). All data were taken under very good seeing conditions (\u223c0\u2033\u200b\u200b.6) in effective exposure times between two and 15 h per pointing, for a total of 125 h. Our observations cover a total solid angle of \u223c23 arcmin&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;sup/&gt; in the direction of clusters, many of which were previously studied by the MAssive Clusters Survey, Frontier Fields (FFs), Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space and Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with &lt;i&gt;Hubble&lt;i/&gt; programmes. The achieved emission line detection limit at 5&lt;i&gt;\u03c3&lt;i/&gt; for a point source varies between (0.77\u20131.5) \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;\u221218&lt;sup/&gt; erg s&lt;sup&gt;\u22121&lt;sup/&gt; cm&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt; at 7000 \u00c5.&lt;i&gt;Methods.&lt;i/&gt; We present our developed strategy to reduce these observational data, detect continuum sources and line emitters in the datacubes, and determine their redshifts. We constructed robust mass models for each cluster to further confirm our redshift measurements using strong-lensing constraints, and identified a total of 312 strongly lensed sources producing 939 multiple images.&lt;i&gt;Results.&lt;i/&gt; The final redshift catalogues contain more than 3300 robust redshifts, of which 40% are for cluster members and \u223c30% are for lensed Lyman-&lt;i&gt;\u03b1&lt;i/&gt; emitters. Fourteen percent of all sources are line emitters that are not seen in the available HST images, even at the depth of the FFs (\u223c29 AB). We find that the magnification distribution of the lensed sources in the high-magnification regime (&lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;\u2004=\u20042\u201325) follows the theoretical expectation of &lt;i&gt;N&lt;i/&gt;(&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;) \u221d &lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt;. The quality of this dataset, number of lensed sources, and number of strong-lensing constraints enables detailed studies of the physical properties of both the lensing cluster and the background galaxies. The full data products from this work, including the datacubes, catalogues, extracted spectra, ancillary images, and mass models, are made available to the community.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=ERC; citation_grant_number=336736;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=V. method=\"post\">\n            <div class=\"wrap\">\n            <div class=\"inputs\">\n                <input type=\"text\" name=\"q\" />\n                <button type=\"submit\" value=\"search\">\n                    <span class=\"ico ico-search\" title=\"Search\"></span>\n                </button>\n            </div> \n                            <div class=\"s_volume_page\">\n                    <a href=\"/component/searcharticle/?by=vol-page\">Access by volume/page</a>\n                </div>\n                        </div>\n\n            <div class=\"advanced\"><a href=\"/component/solr/\">Advanced Search</a></div>\n        </form>\n    </div>\n</div>\n<script type=\"text/javascript\">\n\tjQuery(function ($) {\n\t    var source = function (request, callback) {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div class=\"wrap\">                                  </div>                  \n              </div>\n                    </header>\n\n        <main class=\"aa\" id=\"main\">\n\n            <!--div class=\"wrap\">\n             <p>Message placeholder</p>\n            </div-->\n\n            \n            \n              \n              \n            \n            \n            <div class=\"wrap\" >\n                              \n<div class=\"breadcrumbs\">\n\n\n\n<a href=\"/\" class=\"pathway\">Home</a> <img src=\"/media/system/images/arrow.png\" alt=\"\"  /> <a (2021) A83</a> <img src=\"/media/system/images/arrow.png\" alt=\"\"  /> <span>Full HTML</span></div>\n\n              \n                                                    <div id=\"content\" filters used for the 6 clusters which are not part of the FF or CLASH samples.</p>\n      <div class=\"tab\">\n        <table width=\"100%\" class=\"fm\" frame=\"hsides\" The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: distances and redshifts\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"techniques: imaging spectroscopy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Context.&lt;i/&gt; Spectroscopic surveys of massive galaxy clusters reveal the properties of faint background galaxies thanks to the magnification provided by strong gravitational lensing.&lt;i&gt;Aims.&lt;i/&gt; We present a systematic analysis of integral-field-spectroscopy observations of 12 massive clusters, conducted with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE). All data were taken under very good seeing conditions (\u223c0\u2033\u200b\u200b.6) in effective exposure times between two and 15 h per pointing, for a total of 125 h. Our observations cover a total solid angle of \u223c23 arcmin&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;sup/&gt; in the direction of clusters, many of which were previously studied by the MAssive Clusters Survey, Frontier Fields (FFs), Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space and Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with &lt;i&gt;Hubble&lt;i/&gt; programmes. The achieved emission line detection limit at 5&lt;i&gt;\u03c3&lt;i/&gt; for a point source varies between (0.77\u20131.5) \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;\u221218&lt;sup/&gt; erg s&lt;sup&gt;\u22121&lt;sup/&gt; cm&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt; at 7000 \u00c5.&lt;i&gt;Methods.&lt;i/&gt; We present our developed strategy to reduce these observational data, detect continuum sources and line emitters in the datacubes, and determine their redshifts. We constructed robust mass models for each cluster to further confirm our redshift measurements using strong-lensing constraints, and identified a total of 312 strongly lensed sources producing 939 multiple images.&lt;i&gt;Results.&lt;i/&gt; The final redshift catalogues contain more than 3300 robust redshifts, of which 40% are for cluster members and \u223c30% are for lensed Lyman-&lt;i&gt;\u03b1&lt;i/&gt; emitters. Fourteen percent of all sources are line emitters that are not seen in the available HST images, even at the depth of the FFs (\u223c29 AB). We find that the magnification distribution of the lensed sources in the high-magnification regime (&lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;\u2004=\u20042\u201325) follows the theoretical expectation of &lt;i&gt;N&lt;i/&gt;(&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;) \u221d &lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt;. The quality of this dataset, number of lensed sources, and number of strong-lensing constraints enables detailed studies of the physical properties of both the lensing cluster and the background galaxies. The full data products from this work, including the datacubes, catalogues, extracted spectra, ancillary images, and mass models, are made available to the community.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=ERC; citation_grant_number=336736;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=V. {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div name=\"citation_title\" content=\"An atlas of MUSE observations towards twelve massive lensing clusters\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2021/02/12\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2021/02/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"646\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A83\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/202039462\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2021A%26A...646A..83R\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2021/02/aa39462-20.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: distances and redshifts\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"techniques: imaging spectroscopy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Context.&lt;i/&gt; Spectroscopic surveys of massive galaxy clusters reveal the properties of faint background galaxies thanks to the magnification provided by strong gravitational lensing.&lt;i&gt;Aims.&lt;i/&gt; We present a systematic analysis of integral-field-spectroscopy observations of 12 massive clusters, conducted with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE). All data were taken under very good seeing conditions (\u223c0\u2033\u200b\u200b.6) in effective exposure times between two and 15 h per pointing, for a total of 125 h. Our observations cover a total solid angle of \u223c23 arcmin&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;sup/&gt; in the direction of clusters, many of which were previously studied by the MAssive Clusters Survey, Frontier Fields (FFs), Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space and Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with &lt;i&gt;Hubble&lt;i/&gt; programmes. The achieved emission line detection limit at 5&lt;i&gt;\u03c3&lt;i/&gt; for a point source varies between (0.77\u20131.5) \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;\u221218&lt;sup/&gt; erg s&lt;sup&gt;\u22121&lt;sup/&gt; cm&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt; at 7000 \u00c5.&lt;i&gt;Methods.&lt;i/&gt; We present our developed strategy to reduce these observational data, detect continuum sources and line emitters in the datacubes, and determine their redshifts. We constructed robust mass models for each cluster to further confirm our redshift measurements using strong-lensing constraints, and identified a total of 312 strongly lensed sources producing 939 multiple images.&lt;i&gt;Results.&lt;i/&gt; The final redshift catalogues contain more than 3300 robust redshifts, of which 40% are for cluster members and \u223c30% are for lensed Lyman-&lt;i&gt;\u03b1&lt;i/&gt; emitters. Fourteen percent of all sources are line emitters that are not seen in the available HST images, even at the depth of the FFs (\u223c29 AB). We find that the magnification distribution of the lensed sources in the high-magnification regime (&lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;\u2004=\u20042\u201325) follows the theoretical expectation of &lt;i&gt;N&lt;i/&gt;(&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;) \u221d &lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt;. The quality of this dataset, number of lensed sources, and number of strong-lensing constraints enables detailed studies of the physical properties of both the lensing cluster and the background galaxies. The full data products from this work, including the datacubes, catalogues, extracted spectra, ancillary images, and mass models, are made available to the community.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=ERC; citation_grant_number=336736;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=V. Abril-Melgarejo;citation_author=B. Epinat;citation_author=W. distances and redshifts\">\n  <meta name=\"prism.keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"prism.keyword\" content=\"techniques: imaging spectroscopy\">\n  <meta {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Univ Lyon, Univ Lyon1, ENS de Lyon, CNRS, Centre de Recherche Astrophysique de Lyon UMR5574, 69230 Saint-Genis-Laval, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"An atlas of MUSE observations towards twelve massive lensing clusters\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2021/02/12\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2021/02/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"646\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A83\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/202039462\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2021A%26A...646A..83R\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2021/02/aa39462-20.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: distances and redshifts\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"techniques: imaging spectroscopy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Context.&lt;i/&gt; Spectroscopic surveys of massive galaxy clusters reveal the properties of faint background galaxies thanks to the magnification provided by strong gravitational lensing.&lt;i&gt;Aims.&lt;i/&gt; We present a systematic analysis of integral-field-spectroscopy observations of 12 massive clusters, conducted with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE). All data were taken under very good seeing conditions (\u223c0\u2033\u200b\u200b.6) in effective exposure times between two and 15 h per pointing, for a total of 125 h. Our observations cover a total solid angle of \u223c23 arcmin&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;sup/&gt; in the direction of clusters, many of which were previously studied by the MAssive Clusters Survey, Frontier Fields (FFs), Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space and Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with &lt;i&gt;Hubble&lt;i/&gt; programmes. The achieved emission line detection limit at 5&lt;i&gt;\u03c3&lt;i/&gt; for a point source varies between (0.77\u20131.5) \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;\u221218&lt;sup/&gt; erg s&lt;sup&gt;\u22121&lt;sup/&gt; cm&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt; at 7000 \u00c5.&lt;i&gt;Methods.&lt;i/&gt; We present our developed strategy to reduce these observational data, detect continuum sources and line emitters in the datacubes, and determine their redshifts. We constructed robust mass models for each cluster to further confirm our redshift measurements using strong-lensing constraints, and identified a total of 312 strongly lensed sources producing 939 multiple images.&lt;i&gt;Results.&lt;i/&gt; The final redshift catalogues contain more than 3300 robust redshifts, of which 40% are for cluster members and \u223c30% are for lensed Lyman-&lt;i&gt;\u03b1&lt;i/&gt; emitters. Fourteen percent of all sources are line emitters that are not seen in the available HST images, even at the depth of the FFs (\u223c29 AB). We find that the magnification distribution of the lensed sources in the high-magnification regime (&lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;\u2004=\u20042\u201325) follows the theoretical expectation of &lt;i&gt;N&lt;i/&gt;(&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;) \u221d &lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt;. The quality of this dataset, number of lensed sources, and number of strong-lensing constraints enables detailed studies of the physical properties of both the lensing cluster and the background galaxies. The full data products from this work, including the datacubes, catalogues, extracted spectra, ancillary images, and mass models, are made available to the community.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=ERC; citation_grant_number=336736;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=V. Abril-Melgarejo;citation_author=B. Epinat;citation_author=W. Mercier;citation_publication_date=2021;citation_journal_title=A&amp;A;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=A. Acebron;citation_author=E. Jullo;citation_author=M. Limousin;citation_publication_date=2017;citation_journal_title=MNRAS;citation_volume=470;citation_firstpage=1809;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=T. P. Robitaille;citation_publication_date=2013;citation_journal_title=A&amp;A;citation_volume=558;citation_firstpage=A33;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=H. Atek;citation_author=J. Richard;citation_author=J.-P. {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div name=\"citation_title\" content=\"An atlas of MUSE observations towards twelve massive lensing clusters\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2021/02/12\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2021/02/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"646\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A83\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/202039462\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2021A%26A...646A..83R\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2021/02/aa39462-20.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: distances and redshifts\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"techniques: imaging spectroscopy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Context.&lt;i/&gt; Spectroscopic surveys of massive galaxy clusters reveal the properties of faint background galaxies thanks to the magnification provided by strong gravitational lensing.&lt;i&gt;Aims.&lt;i/&gt; We present a systematic analysis of integral-field-spectroscopy observations of 12 massive clusters, conducted with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE). All data were taken under very good seeing conditions (\u223c0\u2033\u200b\u200b.6) in effective exposure times between two and 15 h per pointing, for a total of 125 h. Our observations cover a total solid angle of \u223c23 arcmin&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;sup/&gt; in the direction of clusters, many of which were previously studied by the MAssive Clusters Survey, Frontier Fields (FFs), Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space and Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with &lt;i&gt;Hubble&lt;i/&gt; programmes. The achieved emission line detection limit at 5&lt;i&gt;\u03c3&lt;i/&gt; for a point source varies between (0.77\u20131.5) \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;\u221218&lt;sup/&gt; erg s&lt;sup&gt;\u22121&lt;sup/&gt; cm&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt; at 7000 \u00c5.&lt;i&gt;Methods.&lt;i/&gt; We present our developed strategy to reduce these observational data, detect continuum sources and line emitters in the datacubes, and determine their redshifts. We constructed robust mass models for each cluster to further confirm our redshift measurements using strong-lensing constraints, and identified a total of 312 strongly lensed sources producing 939 multiple images.&lt;i&gt;Results.&lt;i/&gt; The final redshift catalogues contain more than 3300 robust redshifts, of which 40% are for cluster members and \u223c30% are for lensed Lyman-&lt;i&gt;\u03b1&lt;i/&gt; emitters. Fourteen percent of all sources are line emitters that are not seen in the available HST images, even at the depth of the FFs (\u223c29 AB). We find that the magnification distribution of the lensed sources in the high-magnification regime (&lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;\u2004=\u20042\u201325) follows the theoretical expectation of &lt;i&gt;N&lt;i/&gt;(&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;) \u221d &lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt;. The quality of this dataset, number of lensed sources, and number of strong-lensing constraints enables detailed studies of the physical properties of both the lensing cluster and the background galaxies. The full data products from this work, including the datacubes, catalogues, extracted spectra, ancillary images, and mass models, are made available to the community.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=ERC; citation_grant_number=336736;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=V. {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div name=\"citation_title\" content=\"An atlas of MUSE observations towards twelve massive lensing clusters\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2021/02/12\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2021/02/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"646\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A83\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/202039462\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2021A%26A...646A..83R\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2021/02/aa39462-20.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: distances and redshifts\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"techniques: imaging spectroscopy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Context.&lt;i/&gt; Spectroscopic surveys of massive galaxy clusters reveal the properties of faint background galaxies thanks to the magnification provided by strong gravitational lensing.&lt;i&gt;Aims.&lt;i/&gt; We present a systematic analysis of integral-field-spectroscopy observations of 12 massive clusters, conducted with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE). All data were taken under very good seeing conditions (\u223c0\u2033\u200b\u200b.6) in effective exposure times between two and 15 h per pointing, for a total of 125 h. Our observations cover a total solid angle of \u223c23 arcmin&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;sup/&gt; in the direction of clusters, many of which were previously studied by the MAssive Clusters Survey, Frontier Fields (FFs), Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space and Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with &lt;i&gt;Hubble&lt;i/&gt; programmes. The achieved emission line detection limit at 5&lt;i&gt;\u03c3&lt;i/&gt; for a point source varies between (0.77\u20131.5) \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;\u221218&lt;sup/&gt; erg s&lt;sup&gt;\u22121&lt;sup/&gt; cm&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt; at 7000 \u00c5.&lt;i&gt;Methods.&lt;i/&gt; We present our developed strategy to reduce these observational data, detect continuum sources and line emitters in the datacubes, and determine their redshifts. We constructed robust mass models for each cluster to further confirm our redshift measurements using strong-lensing constraints, and identified a total of 312 strongly lensed sources producing 939 multiple images.&lt;i&gt;Results.&lt;i/&gt; The final redshift catalogues contain more than 3300 robust redshifts, of which 40% are for cluster members and \u223c30% are for lensed Lyman-&lt;i&gt;\u03b1&lt;i/&gt; emitters. Fourteen percent of all sources are line emitters that are not seen in the available HST images, even at the depth of the FFs (\u223c29 AB). We find that the magnification distribution of the lensed sources in the high-magnification regime (&lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;\u2004=\u20042\u201325) follows the theoretical expectation of &lt;i&gt;N&lt;i/&gt;(&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;) \u221d &lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt;. The quality of this dataset, number of lensed sources, and number of strong-lensing constraints enables detailed studies of the physical properties of both the lensing cluster and the background galaxies. The full data products from this work, including the datacubes, catalogues, extracted spectra, ancillary images, and mass models, are made available to the community.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=ERC; citation_grant_number=336736;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=V. {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Univ Lyon, Univ Lyon1, ENS de Lyon, CNRS, Centre de Recherche Astrophysique de Lyon UMR5574, 69230 Saint-Genis-Laval, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"An atlas of MUSE observations towards twelve massive lensing clusters\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2021/02/12\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2021/02/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"646\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A83\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/202039462\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2021A%26A...646A..83R\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2021/02/aa39462-20.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: distances and redshifts\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"techniques: imaging spectroscopy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Context.&lt;i/&gt; Spectroscopic surveys of massive galaxy clusters reveal the properties of faint background galaxies thanks to the magnification provided by strong gravitational lensing.&lt;i&gt;Aims.&lt;i/&gt; We present a systematic analysis of integral-field-spectroscopy observations of 12 massive clusters, conducted with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE). All data were taken under very good seeing conditions (\u223c0\u2033\u200b\u200b.6) in effective exposure times between two and 15 h per pointing, for a total of 125 h. Our observations cover a total solid angle of \u223c23 arcmin&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;sup/&gt; in the direction of clusters, many of which were previously studied by the MAssive Clusters Survey, Frontier Fields (FFs), Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space and Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with &lt;i&gt;Hubble&lt;i/&gt; programmes. The achieved emission line detection limit at 5&lt;i&gt;\u03c3&lt;i/&gt; for a point source varies between (0.77\u20131.5) \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;\u221218&lt;sup/&gt; erg s&lt;sup&gt;\u22121&lt;sup/&gt; cm&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt; at 7000 \u00c5.&lt;i&gt;Methods.&lt;i/&gt; We present our developed strategy to reduce these observational data, detect continuum sources and line emitters in the datacubes, and determine their redshifts. We constructed robust mass models for each cluster to further confirm our redshift measurements using strong-lensing constraints, and identified a total of 312 strongly lensed sources producing 939 multiple images.&lt;i&gt;Results.&lt;i/&gt; The final redshift catalogues contain more than 3300 robust redshifts, of which 40% are for cluster members and \u223c30% are for lensed Lyman-&lt;i&gt;\u03b1&lt;i/&gt; emitters. Fourteen percent of all sources are line emitters that are not seen in the available HST images, even at the depth of the FFs (\u223c29 AB). We find that the magnification distribution of the lensed sources in the high-magnification regime (&lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;\u2004=\u20042\u201325) follows the theoretical expectation of &lt;i&gt;N&lt;i/&gt;(&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;) \u221d &lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt;. The quality of this dataset, number of lensed sources, and number of strong-lensing constraints enables detailed studies of the physical properties of both the lensing cluster and the background galaxies. The full data products from this work, including the datacubes, catalogues, extracted spectra, ancillary images, and mass models, are made available to the community.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=ERC; citation_grant_number=336736;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=V. Abril-Melgarejo;citation_author=B. Epinat;citation_author=W. Mercier;citation_publication_date=2021;citation_journal_title=A&amp;A;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=A. Acebron;citation_author=E. Jullo;citation_author=M. Limousin;citation_publication_date=2017;citation_journal_title=MNRAS;citation_volume=470;citation_firstpage=1809;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=T. P. Bradley;citation_publication_date=2012;citation_journal_title=ApJ;citation_volume=747;citation_firstpage=L9;\">\n  <meta name=\"prism.copyright\" content=\"\u00a9 J. Richard et al. 2021\">\n  <meta name=\"prism.publicationName\" content=\"Astronomy &amp; Astrophysics\">\n  <meta name=\"prism.coverDisplayDate\" content=\"February 2021\">\n  <meta distances and redshifts\">\n  <meta name=\"prism.keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"prism.keyword\" content=\"techniques: imaging spectroscopy\">\n  <meta general\">\n  <meta name=\"prism.url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_world_readable\" content=\"\">\n\n {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div <div>\r\n    \n<div class=\"special_article gold\">Open Access</div>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div id=\"article\">\r\n    <?xml version=\"1.0\" encoding=\"ASCII\" standalone=\"yes\"?>\n<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC \"-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN\" \"\">\n\n    <div id=\"annex\">\n      <h2 class=\"sec\">Table 4. </h2>\n      <p>Summary of all spectroscopic measurements.</p>\n      <div class=\"tab\">\n        <table width=\"100%\" class=\"fm\" frame=\"hsides\" rules=\"groups\">\n<thead>\n<tr>\n<th align=\"left\">Cluster</th>\n<th align=\"center\">Nz</th>\n<th align=\"center\"><i>z</i><sub>min</sub>&#8211;<i>z</i><sub>max</sub></th>\n<th align=\"center\"><i>z</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>z</i><sub>min</sub></th>\n<th align=\"center\"><i>z</i><sub>min</sub>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>z</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>z</i><sub>max</sub></th>\n<th align=\"center\"><i>z</i><sub>max</sub>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>z</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;1.5</th>\n<th align=\"center\">1.5&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>z</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;2.9</th>\n<th align=\"center\"><i>z</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;2.9</th>\n</tr>\n</thead>\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"left\">A2744</td>\n<td align=\"center\">506 (<b>471</b>)</td>\n<td align=\"center\">0.280&#8211;0.340</td>\n<td align=\"center\">28 (<b>28</b>)</td>\n<td align=\"center\">158 (<b>153</b>)</td>\n<td align=\"center\">115 (<b>113</b>)</td>\n<td align=\"center\">29 (<b>23</b>)</td>\n<td align=\"center\">176 (<b>154</b>)</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"left\">A370</td>\n<td align=\"center\">572 (<b>546</b>)</td>\n<td align=\"center\">0.340&#8211;0.410</td>\n<td align=\"center\">62 (<b>60</b>)</td>\n<td align=\"center\">244 (<b>227</b>)</td>\n<td align=\"center\">148 align=\"center\">3827 (<b>3327</b>)</td>\n<td align=\"center\">&#8211;</td>\n<td align=\"center\">321 (<b>290</b>)</td>\n<td align=\"center\">1441 (<b>1296</b>)</td>\n<td align=\"center\">780 (<b>714</b>)</td>\n<td align=\"center\">201 (<b>148</b>)</td>\n<td align=\"center\">1084 (<b>879</b>)</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n      </div>\n      <div class=\"history\">\n<p><b>Notes.</b> For each cluster we provide the total number of redshifts measured as well as in separate redshift bins: in the foreground, in the cluster, and in the background. The cluster redshift limits are defined from the velocity distributions and given as <i>z</i><sub>min</sub>&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>z</i><sub>max</sub>. Numbers given in boldface are limited to the sources with high confidence redshifts (<i>zconf</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;1).</p>\n</div>\n    </div>\n  \n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/202039462\" data-edps_ref=\"aa39462-20\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Univ Lyon, Univ Lyon1, ENS de Lyon, CNRS, Centre de Recherche Astrophysique de Lyon UMR5574, 69230 Saint-Genis-Laval, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"An atlas of MUSE observations towards twelve massive lensing clusters\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2021/02/12\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2021/02/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"646\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A83\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/202039462\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2021A%26A...646A..83R\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2021/02/aa39462-20.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: distances and redshifts\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"techniques: imaging spectroscopy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Context.&lt;i/&gt; Spectroscopic surveys of massive galaxy clusters reveal the properties of faint background galaxies thanks to the magnification provided by strong gravitational lensing.&lt;i&gt;Aims.&lt;i/&gt; We present a systematic analysis of integral-field-spectroscopy observations of 12 massive clusters, conducted with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE). All data were taken under very good seeing conditions (\u223c0\u2033\u200b\u200b.6) in effective exposure times between two and 15 h per pointing, for a total of 125 h. Our observations cover a total solid angle of \u223c23 arcmin&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;sup/&gt; in the direction of clusters, many of which were previously studied by the MAssive Clusters Survey, Frontier Fields (FFs), Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space and Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with &lt;i&gt;Hubble&lt;i/&gt; programmes. The achieved emission line detection limit at 5&lt;i&gt;\u03c3&lt;i/&gt; for a point source varies between (0.77\u20131.5) \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;\u221218&lt;sup/&gt; erg s&lt;sup&gt;\u22121&lt;sup/&gt; cm&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt; at 7000 \u00c5.&lt;i&gt;Methods.&lt;i/&gt; We present our developed strategy to reduce these observational data, detect continuum sources and line emitters in the datacubes, and determine their redshifts. We constructed robust mass models for each cluster to further confirm our redshift measurements using strong-lensing constraints, and identified a total of 312 strongly lensed sources producing 939 multiple images.&lt;i&gt;Results.&lt;i/&gt; The final redshift catalogues contain more than 3300 robust redshifts, of which 40% are for cluster members and \u223c30% are for lensed Lyman-&lt;i&gt;\u03b1&lt;i/&gt; emitters. Fourteen percent of all sources are line emitters that are not seen in the available HST images, even at the depth of the FFs (\u223c29 AB). We find that the magnification distribution of the lensed sources in the high-magnification regime (&lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;\u2004=\u20042\u201325) follows the theoretical expectation of &lt;i&gt;N&lt;i/&gt;(&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;) \u221d &lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt;. The quality of this dataset, number of lensed sources, and number of strong-lensing constraints enables detailed studies of the physical properties of both the lensing cluster and the background galaxies. The full data products from this work, including the datacubes, catalogues, extracted spectra, ancillary images, and mass models, are made available to the community.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=ERC; citation_grant_number=336736;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=V. Abril-Melgarejo;citation_author=B. Epinat;citation_author=W. Mercier;citation_publication_date=2021;citation_journal_title=A&amp;A;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=A. Acebron;citation_author=E. Jullo;citation_author=M. Limousin;citation_publication_date=2017;citation_journal_title=MNRAS;citation_volume=470;citation_firstpage=1809;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=T. P. Bradley;citation_publication_date=2012;citation_journal_title=ApJ;citation_volume=747;citation_firstpage=L9;\">\n  <meta name=\"prism.copyright\" content=\"\u00a9 J. Richard et al. 2021\">\n  <meta name=\"prism.publicationName\" content=\"Astronomy &amp; Astrophysics\">\n  <meta name=\"prism.coverDisplayDate\" content=\"February 2021\">\n  <meta distances and redshifts\">\n  <meta name=\"prism.keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"prism.keyword\" content=\"techniques: imaging spectroscopy\">\n  <meta {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html#T9\">B.2</a> for the RXJ1347 mass model.</p>\n      <div class=\"tab\">\n        <table width=\"100%\" class=\"fm\" frame=\"hsides\" name=\"citation_title\" content=\"An atlas of MUSE observations towards twelve massive lensing clusters\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2021/02/12\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2021/02/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"646\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A83\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/202039462\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2021A%26A...646A..83R\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2021/02/aa39462-20.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: distances and redshifts\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"techniques: imaging spectroscopy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Context.&lt;i/&gt; Spectroscopic surveys of massive galaxy clusters reveal the properties of faint background galaxies thanks to the magnification provided by strong gravitational lensing.&lt;i&gt;Aims.&lt;i/&gt; We present a systematic analysis of integral-field-spectroscopy observations of 12 massive clusters, conducted with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE). All data were taken under very good seeing conditions (\u223c0\u2033\u200b\u200b.6) in effective exposure times between two and 15 h per pointing, for a total of 125 h. Our observations cover a total solid angle of \u223c23 arcmin&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;sup/&gt; in the direction of clusters, many of which were previously studied by the MAssive Clusters Survey, Frontier Fields (FFs), Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space and Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with &lt;i&gt;Hubble&lt;i/&gt; programmes. The achieved emission line detection limit at 5&lt;i&gt;\u03c3&lt;i/&gt; for a point source varies between (0.77\u20131.5) \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;\u221218&lt;sup/&gt; erg s&lt;sup&gt;\u22121&lt;sup/&gt; cm&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt; at 7000 \u00c5.&lt;i&gt;Methods.&lt;i/&gt; We present our developed strategy to reduce these observational data, detect continuum sources and line emitters in the datacubes, and determine their redshifts. We constructed robust mass models for each cluster to further confirm our redshift measurements using strong-lensing constraints, and identified a total of 312 strongly lensed sources producing 939 multiple images.&lt;i&gt;Results.&lt;i/&gt; The final redshift catalogues contain more than 3300 robust redshifts, of which 40% are for cluster members and \u223c30% are for lensed Lyman-&lt;i&gt;\u03b1&lt;i/&gt; emitters. Fourteen percent of all sources are line emitters that are not seen in the available HST images, even at the depth of the FFs (\u223c29 AB). We find that the magnification distribution of the lensed sources in the high-magnification regime (&lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;\u2004=\u20042\u201325) follows the theoretical expectation of &lt;i&gt;N&lt;i/&gt;(&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;) \u221d &lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt;. The quality of this dataset, number of lensed sources, and number of strong-lensing constraints enables detailed studies of the physical properties of both the lensing cluster and the background galaxies. The full data products from this work, including the datacubes, catalogues, extracted spectra, ancillary images, and mass models, are made available to the community.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=ERC; citation_grant_number=336736;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=V. {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div the mass distribution in each cluster.</p>\n      <div class=\"tab\">\n        <table width=\"100%\" class=\"fm\" frame=\"hsides\" rules=\"groups\">\n<thead>\n<tr>\n<th class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq259.gif\" width=\"31\" height=\"20\" /></span></td>\n<td align=\"center\"><span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2021/02/aa39462-20/aa39462-20-eq260.gif\" width=\"39\" height=\"20\" /></span></td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n      </div>\n      <div class=\"history\">\n<p><b>Notes.</b> From left to right: mass component, position relative to cluster centre (&#916;RA and &#916;Dec), dPIE shape (ellipticity and orientation), core and cut radii, velocity dispersion. The final row is the generic galaxy mass at the characteristic luminosity <i>L</i><sup>*</sup>, which is scaled to match each of cluster member galaxies. Parameters in square brackets are fixed a priori in the model.</p>\n</div>\n    </div>\n  \n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/202039462\" data-edps_ref=\"aa39462-20\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. content=\"galaxies: formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Context.&lt;i/&gt; Spectroscopic surveys of massive galaxy clusters reveal the properties of faint background galaxies thanks to the magnification provided by strong gravitational lensing.&lt;i&gt;Aims.&lt;i/&gt; We present a systematic analysis of integral-field-spectroscopy observations of 12 massive clusters, conducted with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE). All data were taken under very good seeing conditions (\u223c0\u2033\u200b\u200b.6) in effective exposure times between two and 15 h per pointing, for a total of 125 h. Our observations cover a total solid angle of \u223c23 arcmin&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;sup/&gt; in the direction of clusters, many of which were previously studied by the MAssive Clusters Survey, Frontier Fields (FFs), Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space and Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with &lt;i&gt;Hubble&lt;i/&gt; programmes. The achieved emission line detection limit at 5&lt;i&gt;\u03c3&lt;i/&gt; for a point source varies between (0.77\u20131.5) \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;\u221218&lt;sup/&gt; erg s&lt;sup&gt;\u22121&lt;sup/&gt; cm&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt; at 7000 \u00c5.&lt;i&gt;Methods.&lt;i/&gt; We present our developed strategy to reduce these observational data, detect continuum sources and line emitters in the datacubes, and determine their redshifts. We constructed robust mass models for each cluster to further confirm our redshift measurements using strong-lensing constraints, and identified a total of 312 strongly lensed sources producing 939 multiple images.&lt;i&gt;Results.&lt;i/&gt; The final redshift catalogues contain more than 3300 robust redshifts, of which 40% are for cluster members and \u223c30% are for lensed Lyman-&lt;i&gt;\u03b1&lt;i/&gt; emitters. Fourteen percent of all sources are line emitters that are not seen in the available HST images, even at the depth of the FFs (\u223c29 AB). We find that the magnification distribution of the lensed sources in the high-magnification regime (&lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;\u2004=\u20042\u201325) follows the theoretical expectation of &lt;i&gt;N&lt;i/&gt;(&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;) \u221d &lt;i&gt;\u03bc&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sup&gt;\u22122&lt;sup/&gt;. The quality of this dataset, number of lensed sources, and number of strong-lensing constraints enables detailed studies of the physical properties of both the lensing cluster and the background galaxies. The full data products from this work, including the datacubes, catalogues, extracted spectra, ancillary images, and mass models, are made available to the community.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=ERC; citation_grant_number=336736;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=V.
